1825.subtitle:
Unit 1, South Eastern England, Unit 2, The Midlands and Unit 3, Scotland and
Northumbria

1829.subtitle: Southern England; Northern England/Scotland. (Two games with the same rules)

1847.subtitle:
Pfalz area of Germany (I {KT} have two versions of 1847, both claiming to be
version 10.1 - but the rules are not identical. One copy refers to the basic game and
extension A. The other refers to the basic game and the expert game, and also variants 5
and 6, for different player counts. Entries are from this version, which was the most
recent purchase.)

1822+.subtitle: Expansion for 1822 - consider all 1822 rulings as relevant for 1822+ . The only entry for 1822+ itself is in section 16 - Miscellaneous .

1822MRS.subtitle:
1822MRS (Medium Regional Scenario) England - entries exist for sections
1.1 (starting cash), 2.5 (certificate limits) and 15.2 (trains) - use 1822 entries for all
other aspects

1824 v2.subtitle: Austria-Hungary - Fox in the Box version (2019)

1830 v2.subtitle:
Northeastern USA - Mayfair Games/Lookout Games version (2011) - entries
cover the base game, excluding variants and the 1830+ scenarios - see entries for v1 or v3
for the classic game

1830Lummerland.subtitle:
Lummerland is an island from the novel for children 'Jim
Knopf and Lukas the engine driver' by Michael Ende

1847AE.subtitle: Pfalz area of Germany - 25th anniversary edition

1862EA.subtitle:
1862: Railways of the Eastern Counties (1862EA) East Anglia - LMN+B
version (2013)

1862EA v2.subtitle:
1862 v2: Railways of the Eastern Counties (1862EA v2) East Anglia - GMT
Games version (2019)

1869 The Golden Spike.subtitle:
Western USA (Information taken from a Beta Test
Draft copy, April 1996)

1876 v2.subtitle:
Trinidad - unrelated to the earlier 1876 titles other than both being
designed by Peter Jacobi

18GA v2.subtitle: Georgia - version 2 is the version included with 18Dixie

18GM.subtitle:
The 18xx GameMaster - a kit for building your own 18xx game -
entries on this list are for The Aurora Limited, the 18GM standard rules

18Hexx.subtitle:
A flexible component system to allow playing many types of games -
offers play in 1830 style, 1870 style, 1856 style, but basically play to whatever rule set
you prefer - because of this, there are no entries on this list because there are no
standard rules

rules:
1.2 - Does the price of a private company drop by 5 for no sale in the
first round?

rules.1761: No.
rules.1812: No. If none of the initial set of Private Companies are put up for auction, a new random set of Private Companies are chosen and the game starts again.
rules.1817: No. If no private companies are purchased they are all removed from the game.
rules.1822: No.
rules.1824: No.
rules.1825: No. One private per player dealt at random and sold compulsorily. With more than 4 players, the others get LNWR shares.
rules.1826: No. First player must buy the first private if round passes out.
rules.1831: Not applicable.
rules.1832: Yes, first private only.
rules.1837: 10 subtracted.
rules.1841: Not applicable.
rules.1844: Yes, first private only.
rules.1846: No. Players draw from a mixed deck of private companies and dummy cards, choosing which items to keep. The last drawn private company may be passed round the table, reducing in price by $10 each time it is passed on, until it is either bought, or taken at no cost.
rules.1850: Yes, first private only.
rules.1851: No. One private per player is dealt at random and sold compulsorily.
rules.1856: Yes, first private only.
rules.1858: No.
rules.1859: No. If all players pass, the player putting the private up for auction receives it for free.
rules.1860: No. All auctions start at zero.
rules.1861: Yes, for all private companies. Any private company price may drop to zero as a result of this.
rules.1867: Yes, for all private companies. Any private company price may drop to zero as a result of this.
rules.1870: Yes, first private only.
rules.1873: Not applicable. But after the initial auction, a Dutch auction commences with 10 subtracted whenever all players pass.
rules.1880: No.
rules.1881: Not applicable.
rules.1883: Yes, first private only.
rules.1889: Yes, Takamatsu ER(A) only. Must buy if 0 Yen.
rules.1891: Yes, first private only.
rules.1893: No, but any starting package certificates unsold after the first round are offered for sale in the next SR. If nobody wants the offered certificate, its price is reduced by 10 until the offered price is 50% (rounded up) of the initial price. If nobody wants it at that price, the player offering it has to buy it, or if they do not have enough cash, the player to their right. This procedure is repeated for the remaining starting package certificates.
rules.1898: Not applicable.
rules.2038: No.
rules.1822CA: No.
rules.1824 v2: No.
rules.18CZ: No.
rules.18NYC: No.
rules.18Scan: No.
rules.Poseidon: No.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Yes, first private only.
rules.18CLE: Yes, first private only.
rules.18GM: Yes, first private only.
rules.18Ireland: Yes, first private only.
rules.18NK: Yes, first private only.
rules.18NY: Yes, first private only.
rules.18USA: No. If no private companies are purchased they are all removed from the game.
rules.18NW: No. First player must buy the first private if round passes out.
rules.1829 Mainline: Not applicable - initial share holdings are dealt, not sold.
rules.1862EA: Not applicable.
rules.1862EA v2: Not applicable.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Not applicable.
rules.18EU: Not applicable.
rules.18West: Not applicable.
rules.1830NL: Yes, but the second company, not the first, which pays no dividend.
rules.1869 USA West: No. The price for all unsold privates drops by 10 if a stock round ends with one or more privates unsold. In the second stock round, if nobody buys the first private, the first player must buy it for 1.
rules.18??: No. Any set of private companies not bid on when all players pass is removed from the game.
rules.18C2C: Yes, but after an operating round. May apply to the Great River Shipping Company and/or the Schuykill Valley Railroad.
rules.18FL: No. Privates are bought at face value, following a bidding process to determine the order in which players make their purchases. 18US has Concessions instead of Privates.
rules.18US: No. Privates are bought at face value, following a bidding process to determine the order in which players make their purchases. 18US has Concessions instead of Privates.
rules.18GB: No. If any privates are not sold when all players pass, those with bids a re sold and the unsold privates are redcued in price by 10.
rules.18GL: No. If all players pass without buying the first private, the player with the priority must buy it for its face value.
rules.18IN: No. If all players pass without buying the first private, the player with the priority must buy it for 25 (face value 30). Furthermore, if all players subsequently pass and at least one private has been bid on, the face value of all privates without bids is reduced by 10. This can occur multiple times. If any private's face value become zero, the player with the priority gains that item for nothing.
rules.18MW: No. There are in effect seven simultaneous auctions for the privates.
rules.18Neb: No. If all palyers pass consecutively during the first stock round, the face value for any items without bids is reduced by 10. This may happen more than once.
rules.18NL: Yes, for the first two privates only.
rules.18OE: Yes. If all players pass before the entire opening packet has been sold, all items on the topmost row are reduced by 5.
rules.18SA: No. If all players pass before all private companies are sold, the unsold private companies are removed from the game.
rules.18VA: No. A series of auction is undertaken. Any private that has not been bid on at the end of each auction is reduced in price by 10.
rules.Steam Over Holland: No. A number of privates equal to the number of players are selected at random and auctioned in sequence. If nobody bids the private is removed from the game.

rules: 2.6 - What are the player certificate limits for shares in one company?

rules.1812: Normally 60%. This can be exceeded, up to 100%, due to Minor Companies taken over by Public Companies.
rules.1817: 100% for 2-share companies, 60% for 5-share and 10-share companies.
rules.1822: Normally 60%. This can be exceeded, up to 100%, due to Minor Companies taken over by Public Companies.
rules.1824: Normally 60%. This can be exceeded, up to 100%, due to exchanges with Mountain Railways or Coal Railways.
rules.1830: 5 certificates. Shares in the orange and brown zones do not count towards this. Note that if you play the Reading variant you may hold 70% of the Reading.
rules.1831: None, unless Government intervention is in play, then 70%.
rules.1832: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'. Shares in orange and brown zones do not count towards this.
rules.1837: 60%. This may be exceeded by minor company exchange but the excess must then be sold at the next opportunity.
rules.1841: 60%. This applies to the total number of shares under each player's control. It may be exceeded by transfers of control but the excess must then be sold at the next opportunity.
rules.1842: 60%. Shares in the marked zone of the stock market do not count towards this.
rules.1844: None. But once the player has more than 50% of a company, he may not buy its shares from the initial offering.
rules.1848: In a 3-player game, 70%. In a 4-, 5- or 6-player game, 60%.
rules.1850: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'. Shares in orange and brown zones do not count towards this.
rules.1853: 3 or 4 players, 60%; 5 players, 50%; 6 players, 40%. Shares worth 40 or less do not count towards this.
rules.1856: 60%. Shares in the brown zone do not count towards this.
rules.1858: Normally 60%, but can be exceeded in the Final Exchange Round, with no requirement to sell back down.
rules.1860: None.
rules.1862: 70% if there are 3 or 4 solvent players, and 60% if there are 5 or more solvent players. Thus if a company redeems half its shares one player may be able to own all that is left of it.
rules.1870: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'. Shares in orange and brown zones do not count towards this.
rules.1873: None.
rules.1880: None.
rules.1889: 60%. Shares in the brown zone do not count towards this.
rules.1891: 60%. Shares in the brown zone do not count towards this.
rules.1898: 60%. This applies to the total number of shares under each player's control. It may be exceeded by transfers of control but the excess must then be sold at the next opportunity.
rules.1822CA: Normally 60%. This can be exceeded, up to 100%, due to Minor Companies taken over by Public Companies.
rules.18USA: 100% for 2-share companies, 60% for 5-share and 10-share companies.
rules.1824 v2: Normally 60%. This can be exceeded, up to 100%, due to exchanges with Mountain Railways or Coal Railways. For the Cisleithania 2-player variant, shares bought from the bank pool may exceed the 60% limit.
rules: None.
rules.1862EA: None.
rules.1862EA v2: None.
rules.18C2C: None.
rules.Poseidon: None.
rules.18??: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'. Shares in orange and brown zones do not count towards this.
rules.18GM: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'. Shares in orange and brown zones do not count towards this.
rules.18MW: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'. Shares in orange and brown zones do not count towards this.
rules.18EU: 60%. This may be exceeded by minor company exchange but the excess must then be sold at the next opportunity.
rules.1853 v2: 3 or 4 players, 60%; 5 players, 50%; 6 players, 40%. Shares worth 40 or less do not count towards this.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Players, 60%, Dragons (foreign investors) 50%.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: 60%, including the option of one share purchased on a 50% margin. Additional growth shares may be purchased from the bank pool, but dividends go to the company treasury rather than the owning player.
rules.18Ardennes: 60% when bought from the initial offering. This can rise to 100% for purchases from the bank pool and Minor Company exchanges.
rules.18BL: 60%, or 70% if a payer already owns 60% and buys a further share from the initial offering.
rules.18CZ: Standard game: 60% of a medium or large company, 75% of a small company. Bohemia and Moravia-Silesia Variants: 70% of a large company.
rules.18Dixie: 60% excluding preferred shares. It is possible to hold up to 80% of some companies (90% of the L&N) by owning all preferred shares in addition to the regular allowance.
rules.18GB: 60% when bought from the initial offering. Purchases from the bank pool or for shares in the orange zone do not count towards this. When ten-share companies are formed, five shares will be in the bank pool and so will not count towards this limit.
rules.18Ireland: 60% for 5-share companies, 70% for 10-share companies.
rules.18Lilliput: 80%, which is all the shares available an any company.
rules.18Neb: 60%. As an optional rule in the two-player game only, players may allow up to 70% ownership in each ten-share company.
rules.18NK: 60%; may be exceeded by 'price protection'.
rules.18NY: 60%. This may be exceeded when buying shares from the bank pool.
rules.18OE: None, but for major and national companies, a player who owns 60% may only gain more by merging a minor or buying from the bank pool at twice the current share value.
rules.18PA: 60%, raised by one certificate for each local company acquired by a public company. It is possible for this variable limit to be exceeded during the conversion and acquisition steps of an OR. If this happens the player must sell certificates at the start of the next SR to comply with the current limit.
rules.18US: For 4-share and 5-share companies, up to 3 shares, for 10-share companies, up to 5 shares, for systems, all 10 shares.
rules.18West: 60%; may be exceeded by 'acquisition'.
rules.Crisis: 50% for type I companies, 60% for type II companies. Shares in the blue and grey zones do not count towards this.

rules: 2.7 - Does the stock price drop when stock is sold?

rules.1761: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.1812: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.1817: No.
rules.1822: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1824: Yes, 1 row per block.
rules.1826: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1831: No for preferred stock, complex for common stock.
rules.1832: Yes, 1 row per share, but if this means it would end up one row below the ledge, then it stops above the ledge. Share prices do not change until after a player's stock turn and any ensuing 'price protection'.
rules.1837: Yes, 1 row (down and to the left) per block.
rules.1841: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1842: Yes, 1 row for a sale of 10% or 20%; 2 rows for a sale of 30% or more.
rules.1844: Yes, 1 row per block.
rules.1846: Yes, 1 column per block of shares sold, but only when sold by the company President.
rules.1850: Yes, 1 row per share, but if this means it would end up one row below the ledge, then it stops above the ledge. Share prices do not change until after a player's stock turn and any ensuing 'price protection'.
rules.1854: Yes, 1 row (down and to the left) per certificate.
rules.1856: Yes, 1 row per complete 10% sold; e.g. selling 25% drops the price two rows. The CGR's price cannot change for any reason until it owns a permanent train.
rules.1858: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.1859: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1860: Yes, if the company has operated.The price moves down once for each share sold, zig-zagging between the top and bottom levels. However, when shares are worth less than 40 or more than 150, the first share sold has no effect on the share price, i.e. the price moves down one less space than normal. Once the 8+4 train is bought, sales do not reduce share prices.
rules.1861: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.1867: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.1870: Yes, 1 row per share, but if this means it would end up one row below the ledge, then it stops above the ledge. Share prices do not change until after a player's stock turn and any ensuing 'price protection'.
rules.1873: Yes, 1 row per share,m but only if it has already operated.
rules.1880: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1881: Yes, 1 row per block.
rules.1883: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1891: Yes, 1 row per complete 10% sold; e.g. selling 25% drops the price two rows. The JNR's price cannot change for any reason until it owns a permanent train.
rules.1898: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.2038: Yes, 1 row per block.
rules.18Ruhr: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.Poseidon: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.Railroad Barons: Yes, 1 row per block of shares sold, but only if they are sold by the company Director/President.
rules.1824 v2: Yes, 1 row per block.
rules: Yes, 1 row per block.
rules.18USA: No.
rules.18EU: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18GL: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18GM: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18IN: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18Ireland: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18Neb: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18NW: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18NY: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18OE: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18Scan: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.18VA: Yes, 1 row per share.
rules.1822CA: Yes, 1 row per share if sold by the Director, or 1 row per block if sold by any other player.
Complex. See table in rule 3.3.2, or http://www.fwtwr.com/18xx/rules_difference_list/1827_junior.htm .
rules.1830 Cardgame: Not applicable. Shares may not be sold at any time.
rules.1830BC: Yes, 1 place per share, maximum 3 per block (1 in red zone).
rules.18??: Yes, 1 row per share, but if this means it would end up one row below the ledge, then it stops above the ledge. Share prices do not change until after a player's stock turn and any ensuing 'price protection'.
rules.18US: Yes, 1 column per block of shares sold, but only when sold by the company President.
rules.18West: Yes, 1 column per block of shares sold, but only when sold by the company President.
rules.1862EA: Yes, 1 space per share sold. However, if the share price is above 200 or below 40, and the seller is not the company Director, ignore the first certificate sold. If the price is above 400, ignore the first 2 shares sold. The share price does not fall if the company has not floated, or after the sale of the first H train.
rules.1862EA v2: Yes, 1 space per share sold. However, if the share price is above 200 or below 40, and the seller is not the company Director, ignore the first certificate sold. If the price is above 400, ignore the first 2 shares sold. The share price does not fall if the company has not floated, or after the sale of the first H train.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Yes, 1 row per share sold, but only if they are sold by the company President or a Dragon (foreign investor).
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Yes, 1 row per share from the player's hand, but 1 row per block of grworth shares.
rules.18Ardennes: Yes, 1 row per share sold, but only if they are sold by the company President.
rules.18C2C: Yes, 1 row per share; but if this would take it to just below ledge, then 1 less.
rules.18CLE: Yes, 1 row per share, but if the token is immediately above the ledge, the number of spaces dropped is reduced by 1.
rules.18CZ: Yes, the price moves down once no matter how many shares are sold, zig-zagging between the top and bottom levels.
rules.18FL: Yes, 1 column to the left per block.
rules.18GB: Yes, one space per share sold, except that in the grey phase sales by non-directors do not affect the price.
rules.18Lilliput: Yes, down one value for each share sold.
rules.18NK: Yes, one row per complete 20% sold.
rules.18NYC: 1 row per 10% sold for Lines, 1 row per block for the NYCTA.
rules.18SA: Yes. In the yellow zone, 1 row per 5% sold, in other areas of the stock market, 1 row per 10% sold.
rules.Rolling Stock: Yes, at least 1 place per share, possibly more by leapfrogging. You may only sell one share at a time, and you get paid the lowered share price.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Yes, 1 row per share, but if sold by someone other than the president, can not drop below a ledge. If sold by a company during an OR, it drops 1 row less than the number of shares sold.

rules.Rolling Stock: No, but the share price goes up when a share is bought.

rules: 2.10 - Can companies buy shares?

rules.1761: Privates and minor companies in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold, for 1 to face value.
rules.1800: Their own, in ORs. They can also sell, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn.
rules.1812: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold, and their own from the bank pool, by 'redemption', in ORs.
rules.1817: Their own, in SRs, when the president chooses to act on behalf of the company instead of for himself.
rules.1822: Yes. From phases 2, 3 or 5 (depending on which private company is under consideration), major and minor companies may take private companies from a consenting player. Not all private companies may be taken by minor companies. No compensation is paid to the player. Major companies may also acquire minor companies, and may issue stock from their treasury to the bank pool.
rules.1824: No.
rules.1826: Their own, in ORs.
rules.1830: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1831: Yes, in SRs, limit of 25% of own common stock. May buy up to limit immediately after any share is sold into bank pool.
rules.1832: Their own, by 'redemption', in SRs. Also privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold. The West Virginia Coal Fields can be bought in phase two for half to full face value. The London Investment Company, the Central Rail Road and Canal Company and the Southern Bank (if in play) may not be bought by companies.
rules.1834: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1837: No.
rules.1841: Yes, up to five certificates, but not their own; in ORs.
rules.1844: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1846: Their own; in ORs. Privates, in ORs, in Phases I and II.
rules.1848: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1850: Their own, by 'redemption', in SRs. Also privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold. The Mississippi River Bridge Company and the Mesabi Mining Company can be bought in phase two for half to full face value.
rules.1851: Their own, in ORs. But they may not own more than 50% of themselves.
rules.1856: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1857: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1858: Their own, as the last action when operating. May also issue shares from their second operating turn on.
rules.1859: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1860: No.
rules.1861: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold, and their own from the bank pool, by 'redemption', in ORs.
rules.1867: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold, and their own from the bank pool, by 'redemption', in ORs.
rules.1868: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1870: Their own, by 'redemption', in SRs. Also privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold, for half to double face value. The Mississippi River Bridge Company can be bought by the MP or the SSW in phase one for half to full face value.
rules.1873: No.
rules.1880: No.
rules.1881: Yes, tramway companies may buy and sell S-Bahn certificates.
rules.1883: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1889: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1891: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1898: Yes, up to five certificates, but not their own; in ORs; or they may buy back per turn one of their own from the bank pool to their initial offering.
rules.1899: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.2038: Privates, in ORs, once phase II has started.
rules.18GL: Their own, in ORs. They can also sell, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn.
rules.18Ireland: Their own, in ORs. They can also sell, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn.
rules.18USA: Their own, in SRs, when the president chooses to act on behalf of the company instead of for himself.
rules.1822CA: Yes. From phases 1, 2, 3 or 5 (depending on which private company is under consideration), major and minor companies may take private companies from a consenting player. Not all private companies may be taken by minor companies. No compensation is paid to the player. Major companies may also acquire minor companies, and may issue stock from their treasury to the bank pool.

rules.18SY-G: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.1837SX: Yes, one of their own from the bank pool, which is then placed in the initial offering. They may alternatively sell one of their own shares from the initial offering to the bank pool.
rules.1847 Expert Game: Quarries, in ORs, once a 4 train has been sold.
rules.1847AE: Quarries, in ORs, once a 4 train has been sold.
rules.1862EA: Their own, by 'redemption', in ORs. They may also be required to sell shares to raise funds for forced train purchases.
rules.1862EA v2: Their own, by 'redemption', in ORs. They may also be required to sell shares to raise funds for forced train purchases.
rules.1865 Sardinia: No, but companies may be given Maritime Companies (privates) and may absorb other companies.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: First private only, for half to twice face value.
rules.18??: Their own, by 'redemption', in SRs. Also privates, in ORs, before the purchase of the first '3' train for one half of face value, and once a 3 train has been sold for one half to double face value.
rules.18C2C: Their own, by 'redemption', in SRs. Also privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.18CZ: Companies may acquire smaller companies.
rules.18IN: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold, and their own shares from the bank pool in ORs. They can also sell these shares, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn.
rules.18NY: Their own, in SRs.
rules.18NK: Their own, by 'redemption', in SRs. Also privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.
rules.18NW: Their own, in ORs, but not in their first operating turn. They can also sell, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn.
rules.18NYC: Privates in ORs, and shares from companies that are part of their affiliation (colour) in ORs. They can also sell these shares, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn.
rules.18OE: Major company may buy their own, in ORs. They can also sell, but cannot buy and sell in the same turn. They may also buy one abandoned minor company per OR from the bank pool.
rules.18Ruhr: Their own, in ORs. They may buy or sell a single share, which moves between the bank pool and the initial offering or vice versa. If a share is sold the company gains the current price and the price will fall by one row.
rules.18SA: Their own, from the bank pool, in ORs. But they may not own more than 10% of themselves.
rules.18TN: Privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold. May also buy one private at face value in the first OR of the game.
rules.18US: Western Concessions once the Western Railroad Convention has taken place, except for the Denver and Rio Grande and the Pacific Railway Act.
rules.18West: Yes, Granger Road companies in a Merger and Acquisition round.
rules.Railroad Barons: Yes, Holdings may buy Railroad Corporations (equivalent to trains in most 18xx games).
rules.Steam Over Holland: Yes, their own from the bank pool during ORs. Also privates, in ORs, once a 3 train has been sold.

rules: 2.11 - What ends a share dealing round?

rules.1761: Each player consecutively not making a purchase or a sale. The priority then goes to the player after the one who last made a purchase or a sale.

rules: 3.1 - Do you lay the base station token immediately upon floating?

rules.1761: No.
rules.1812: Yes.
rules.1817: A company's home station is placed when the President's certificate is put up for auction.
rules.1822: No.
rules.1824: No.
rules.1825: The token is placed on the home base at the start of the operating round in which it will first run.
rules.1826: Yes.
rules.1831: No.

rules.1837: Yes.

rules.1847: The token is placed on the home base at the start of the operating round in which it will first run.

rules.1858: Yes.

rules.1860: Yes.

rules.1870: No.
rules.1873: Yes.
rules.1879: All base station tokens start the game on the map.
rules.1880: The token is placed on the home base at the end of the stock round in which the Director owns the qualifying number of shares. The qualifying number of shares depends on the phase. From Phase A1 (the start of the game) it is 20%, from B1 it is 30%, from B3 it is 40% and from C2 it is 60%.
rules.1881: It is recommended that base tokens for the tramway companies are placed upside down on their starting hexes at the beginning of the game. The rules do not say when these are flipped over, but it is assumed this happens when the tramway companies float, because the rules do state that the base tokens for the S-Bahn main company and its three subnets are placed when the S-Bahn floats.
rules.1883: Yes.
rules.1891: Contradictory. As per the 1856 rules, which 1891 is based on, no, and the translated rules state that the token is placed when it first operates. However, the rules on starting a company have an italicised section that states that the token is placed in the starting city when the presidency is purchased.

rules: 3.2 - How many shares must be sold for a company to float?

rules.1817: The President's certificate.
rules.1822: Initially 20% (10% for the LNWR) when converting a concession. From phase 5, 50%.
rules.1824: 50% for regional railways and 20% for Staatsbahnen.
rules.1825: 60% for a major company, 40% for a minor company.
rules.1831: 50% (all preferred stock).
rules.1841: 20% (40% of a minor).
rules.1856: Depends on the type of the train currently for sale.
rules.1858: 40% of a 5-share company, 20% of a 10-share company.
rules.1870: 60%; but 20% for the SLSF.
rules.1880: The qualifying number of shares depends on the phase. From Phase A1 (the start of the game) it is 20%, from B1 it is 30%, from B3 it is 40% and from C2 it is 60%.
rules.1881: Five certificates. This is 60% for tramway companies, 30% for the S-Bahn.
rules.1891: Depends on the type of the train currently for sale.
rules.1898: 20% (40% of a minor).
rules.2038: 50%; but 20% for growth companies.
rules.18USA: The President's certificate.
rules.1822CA: Initially 20% (10% for the CPR) when converting a concession. From phase 5, 50%.
rules.1824 v2: 50% for regional railways and 20% for Staatsbahnen.
rules.1829 Mainline: The Director's certificate, or three ordinary certificates.
rules.18Africa: The Director's certificate, or three ordinary certificates.
rules.18??: 60%; but 30% for any company started by the Grand Junction Investors private.
rules.18CLE: 60%, except for the CSC, which floats at 20%. Rule 3.3.3 refers generally to a company as 'floated' when the 20% President's certificate has been bought - this should say 'started' or 'formed'.
rules.18Dixie: 50%, but 20% for the SAL and SOU if the President's certificates are obtained via the purchase of the GAR or SCCRRC private companies respectively.
rules.18FL: 60% for five-share companies, 50% for ten-share companies.
rules.18NW: 60% for five-share companies, 50% for ten-share companies.
rules.18GB: 40% in the yellow phase; 60% thereafter. No companies may be started in the grey phase.
rules.18Ireland: 40% for a 5-share company, 20% for a 10-share company, i.e. just the director's certificate in both cases.
rules.18Neb: 20% (40% of a Local Company).
rules.18NK: 60%; but 20% for the DRM.
rules.18NY: Dependent on the current game phase (see section 12).
rules.18NYC: 50% for Lies, 10% for the NYCTA.
rules.18OE: For minors, 100%. For regionals, 20%.
rules.18Scan: Depends on the current phase number.
rules.18US: For an Eastern (4-share) company, the President's certificate. For a Land Grant (5-share) company, the President's certificate and one other certificate.
rules.18VA: 20% for ten-share companies, 40% for five-share companies (one certificate in each case).
rules.18West: The President's certificate. The v2.3 retuned rules clarify that after phase 6 begins, five shares must be bought to start a public company.
rules.Crisis: 50% for type I companies, 60% for type II companies.
rules.Poseidon: At least 50% (rounded up) of the Merchants placed in the bank pool by the player who bought the nation's King card.
rules.Steam Over Holland: A number of shares equal to the current phase number, which have to be bought as one purchase.

rules: 3.3 - Does a company get full capitalisation upon floating?

rules.1761: Yes.
rules.1812: Only for shares sold.
rules.1817: Only for shares sold.
rules.1822: Only for shares sold until phase 6, then fully capitalised when floated.
rules.1824: Regional Railways with associated Coal Railways get 8 x the share price. Regional Railways without associated Coal Railways get full capitalisation.
rules.1825: Nine-certificate companies do, four-certificate companies don't.
rules.1826: Only for shares sold until phase 10H, then fully capitalised when floated.
rules.1831: Only for shares sold. (Par increases upon floating.)
rules.1832: Yes.
rules.1837: You get full capitalisation for the shares that have been and will be sold, but not for the coal and minor companies that will fold in.
rules.1841: Only for shares sold.
rules.1844: Regional companies get full capitalisation on floating. Other companies get 50% on floating, the rest when they reach their destination. Companies that float after the sale of a 6/6H train are fully capitalised.
rules.1846: Only as shares are sold or are issued from the company treasury to the bank pool.
rules.1850: Yes.
rules.1854: 100% capitalisation on floating, more on splitting.
rules.1856: Depends on the type of train currently for sale; and on reaching destination.
rules.1858: Only for shares sold.
rules.1859: Yes.
rules.1860: Yes.
rules.1861: Only for shares sold.
rules.1867: Only for shares sold.
rules.1870: Yes.
rules.1873: Yes.
rules.1880: 50% capitalisation at the start of the game. Once the first 3 train is bought, companies with 5 or fewer shares in the bank receive the remaining 50% capitalisation.
rules.1881: Yes.
rules.1883: Only for shares sold.
rules.1891: Depends on the type of train currently for sale; and on reaching destination.
rules.1898: Only for shares sold.
rules.2038: Yes, except for growth companies, which get capitalised for shares sold i.e. excluding the President's double; and for the Asteroid League, which gets capitalisation for the President's double share, and for other shares as sold, but not for independents traded in.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Yes.
rules.18??: Yes.
rules.18C2C: Yes.
rules.18CLE: Yes.
rules.18NK: Yes.
rules: Only for shares sold.

rules.1824 v2: Regional Railways with associated Coal Railways get 8 x the share price. Regional Railways without associated Coal Railways get full capitalisation.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Only as shares are sold or are issued from the company treasury to the bank pool.
rules.1862EA: For companies with a Parliamentary charter (Chartered Companies), 100%. For Non-chartered Companies, only for shares sold.
rules.1862EA v2: For companies with a Parliamentary charter (Chartered Companies), 100%. For Non-chartered Companies, only for shares sold.
rules.18CZ: Yes, but the amount recevied depends on the size of the company. Small = 4 x initial share price, Medium = 5 x, Large = 10 x.
rules.18EU: Only for shares sold until phase 5, then fully capitalised when floated.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: Only for shares sold until phase 5, then fully capitalised when floated.
rules.18Ruhr: Only for shares sold until phase 5, then fully capitalised when floated.
rules.18FL: A five-share company gets five times its starting value, while a ten-share company gets ten times its starting value.
rules.18GB: A five-share company gets five times its starting value, while a ten-share company gets ten times its starting value.
rules.18GM: Depends on the type of train currently for sale.
rules.18Neb: No, it gets it share by share. Ten-share companies that begin in phase 5 receive their remaining capital after the fifth share is sold.
rules.18NY: Prior to the special Capitalisation Round, only for shares sold. After this round, fully capitalised when floated.
rules.18PA: Companies start as five-share companies and get five times their starting value. When converted to ten-share companies they get five times the current market value. The NYC is an exception to this and has its own special formation rules.
rules.18Scan: Only for shares sold in phases 2 to 4, full capitalisation from phase 5 on.
rules.18SY-O: If a company is floated with 60% of the shares sold, full capitalisation. If it is floated with ferwer shares, only for shares sold, with the remaining funds withheld until all shares are bought from the bank.
rules.18US: Yes, when initially floated. 4-share and 5-share companies gain additional capital later on.
rules.18VA: No, it gets it share by share until the sixth share of a ten-share company is sold, when it gets all the rest.
rules.18West: Granger Road companies are fully capitalised. Land Grant and public companies started prior to phase 6 are funded as shares are sold, and fully capitalised once phase 6 has begun.
rules.Rolling Stock: No, it gets capitalisation for all shares issued during launching, minus the face value of the private company used for launching, plus a cash controbution from the player.

rules: 3.4 - How is a share company's initial (par) price determined?

rules.1812: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1817: The President's certificates are auctioned. The initial share price is the final auction bid divided by two, rounded down to the nearest stock price.
rules.1824: For Regional Railways with associated Coal Railways, the price is set by the purchase price of the Coal Railway. For Regional Railways without an associated Coal Railway, the price is set by the player who purchases the Director's certificates. In both cases they choose a value from a range of predefined prices.
rules.1825: Major companies have fixed par prices. For minor companies the price is set by the player who purchases the Presdient's certificate, using any value on the stock market no lower than one tenth the price of the company's built-in train.
rules.1826: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1834: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1837: The three National Railways have fixed par prices. For the seven major companies the initial price is set by the player who purchases the Director's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices.
rules.1841: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price. The exception to this is companies created by a merger or promotion (or the Ferdinandea Succession). These have their initial price calculated from the prices of the predecessor companies.
rules.1846: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1848: The CAR always has an initial price of 100. for all other companies the price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices.
rules.1849: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1851: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1856: For most companies, the price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. For the CGR, the price is calculated from the prices of the companies that form the CGR.
rules.1858: Prior to phase 5, by the face value of the private (rounded down); from phase 5 onwards the Director chooses one of a range of values.
rules.1861: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1867: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1873: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1881: Companies have fixed par prices.
rules.1895: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1898: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.2038: The par values of "growth corporations" (minor companies that have been promoted to major companies) and the TSI and Asteroid League are fixed. For "growth companies" the par value is 67 but the starting market value is only 10. Those of other "public companies" are set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices.
rules.18Ardennes: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.18EU: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.18GB: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.

rules.18SS: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.18VA: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.Rolling Stock: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.Steam Over Holland: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. All further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.1824 v2: For Regional Railways with associated Coal Railways, the price is set by the purchase price of the Coal Railway. For Regional Railways without an associated Coal Railway, the price is set by the player who purchases the Director's certificates. In both cases they choose a value from a range of predefined prices.
rules.1862EA: The price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. For non-chartered companies, the par price is the highest price on the par chart that is equal to or lower than the initial share price.
rules.1862EA v2: The price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. For non-chartered companies, the par price is the highest price on the par chart that is equal to or lower than the initial share price.
rules.18EZ Level 3: For most companies, the price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices. For the Black Line, the price is fixed.
rules.18Ireland: There are no par prices. For a 5-share company the initial price is set at the highest price from a predefined list that is not more than half the winning bid for the company. For a 10-share company the initial price is set by the player who purchases the Director's certificate, choosing a value selected from a list of predefined prices. For both types of company all further share dealing is done at the current market price.
rules.18Lilliput: There are no par prices. The initial price is set by the player who purchases the Director's certificate, choosing any value on the stock market.
rules.18USA: The President's certificates are auctioned. The initial share price is the final auction bid divided by two, rounded down to the nearest stock price between 50 and 200.
rules.Poseidon: The price is set by the player who purchases the nation's King card. It can be set to any value on the Prestige track.
rules.Rest: The price is set by the player who purchases the President's certificate, choosing a value selected from a range of predefined prices.

rules: 4.1 - In what order do companies operate?

rules.1812: Private companies, then Minor companies in descending order of share price, then Public companies in descending order of share price. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next.
rules.1822: Private companies, then Minor companies in descending order of share price, then Public companies in descending order of share price. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next.
rules.1824: Mountain Railways, Coal Railways, pre-Staatsbahnen, then major companies in dynamic share price order (See 'Rest' for details of this).
rules.1825: Major companies in set order of initial value with ties broken by formation order, followed by minor companies from highest par value to lowest with ties broken by formation order.
rules.1846: Current 'dynamic' share price. By 'dynamic', this means that each time a company finishes operating, you look at the current stock price chart to see who is next. The highest value company that has not operated operates next. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next. If two companies have the same value but are in different spaces, the company with a token furthest to the right operates next. For the first operating round only, this is reversed, with the companies operating from lowest to highest price.
rules.1850: The rules simply state (4.1.2) that companies 'operate in share price order'. I have confirmed with John Tamplin that this works as current 'dynamic' share price, as stated under 'rest' below.
rules.1858: Private companies in numerical order, then public companies in price order.
rules.1861: Private companies, then Minor companies in descending order of share price, then Public companies in descending order of share price, then the Russian State Railway. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next. If two companies have the same value but are in different spaces, the company with a token furthest to the right operates next.
rules.1862: Current static price, i.e. in order of stock price as at the start of the operating round.
rules.1867: Private companies, then Minor companies in descending order of share price, then Public companies in descending order of share price, then the Russian State Railway. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next. If two companies have the same value but are in different spaces, the company with a token furthest to the right operates next.
rules.1880: In the order of the turn order list, the positions in this list being chosen by the Director at the time the company becomes operational.
rules.1881: Tramway companies in descending share price order (as in 'Rest' below), then the S-Bahn company.
rules.1899: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. The rules resolve issues where more than one company is on the same priced space by giving preference to companies further to the right, which does not resolve this situation. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules.1822CA: Private companies, then Minor companies in descending order of share price, then Public companies in descending order of share price. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next.
rules.1824 v2: Mountain Railways, Coal Railways, pre-Staatsbahnen, then major companies in dynamic share price order (See 'Rest' for details of this).
rules.1830 v1: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. The rules resolve issues where more than one company is on the same priced space by giving preference to companies further to the right, which does not resolve this situation. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.

The rules resolve issues where more than one company is on the same priced space by giving preference to companies further to the right, which does not resolve this situation. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules.1830Lummerland: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules.1830NL: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. The rules resolve issues where more than one company is on the same priced space by giving preference to companies further to the right, which does not resolve this situation. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules.18Kaas: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. The rules resolve issues where more than one company is on the same priced space by giving preference to companies further to the right, which does not resolve this situation. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules.18NL: As for 'rest' below. However, note the special case of the three value '67' spaces one above the other in the same column. The rules resolve issues where more than one company is on the same priced space by giving preference to companies further to the right, which does not resolve this situation. It seems to be generally agreed that companies further up the chart run first.
rules.1830BC: Order of fewest shares in player hands; ties broken in set order.
rules.18Neb: Current 'dynamic' share price. By 'dynamic', this means that each time a company finishes operating, you look at the current stock price chart to see who is next. The highest value company that has not operated operates next. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next. If two companies have the same value but are in different spaces, the company with a token furthest to the right operates next. For the first operating round only, this is reversed, with the companies operating from lowest to highest price.
rules.18CLE: Current 'dynamic' share price, as stated under 'rest' below. As a one-off exception, in the operating round after the SHR is floated, it will always operate first.
rules.18EU: Minor companies operate in numerical order, followed by major companies as stated under 'rest' below.
rules.18EZ Level 1: In seating order round the table.
rules.18FL: The highest value company that has not operated operates next. If more than one company occupies the same space, the company with a token on top operates first.
rules.18US: The highest value company that has not operated operates next. If more than one company occupies the same space, the company with a token on top operates first.
rules.18IN: Private companies, then minor companies, then major companies, then the Penn Central. The minor companies and major companies operate within their groups by current 'dyanmic' share price (see 'Rest' below for a definition of this). As an exception, in the first operating round companies operate in reverse order.
rules.18Lilliput: Tile laying, station placement and running trains takes place by the play of Action Cards, so there is no specific or guaranteed order for these actions. All companies run their trains in each round, from the highest share price down. The rules do not state the order for companies with the same share price, but it is safe to assume from the top down as newly arriving tokens go to the bottom of the stack.
rules.18NY: Private companies, then Minor companies in descending order of share price, then Public companies in descending order of share price. If two companies have the same price, the company furthest to the rest, then with a token on top operates next.
rules.18OE: Regionals and Minors operate in the order their markers appear on the Regiona/Minor Operating Order track. Then National and Majors operate in share value order, from highest to lwest. If two or more companies have the same value, the marker further to the right operates first. If two or more companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates first.
rules.18Ruhr: Private companies, then active PMCs in ascending numerical order, then Public companies in descending order of share price. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next.
rules.18West: The highest value company that has not operated operates next. If more than one company occupies the same space, the company with a token on top operates first. The v2.3 retuned rules clarify that all Granger Roads operate before all other companies regardless of current market value.
rules.Rolling Stock: Current 'dynamic' share price. By 'dynamic', this means that each time a company finishes operating, you look at the current stock price chart to see who is next. The highest value company that has not operated operates next. Each share price can only be occupied by a single company, so no further ambiguity is possible.
rules.Steam Over Holland: In descending price order, with ties being resolved from left to right.
rules.Rest: Current 'dynamic' share price. By 'dynamic', this means that each time a company finishes operating, you look at the current stock price chart to see who is next. The highest value company that has not operated operates next. If two companies occupy the same space, the company with a token on top operates next. If two companies have the same value but are in different spaces, the company with a token furthest to the right operates next.

rules: 5.1 - Where can you make an initial tile lay?

rules.1761: As for 1830. (rule 11.2)
rules.1812: As for 1830.
rules.1817: As for 1830. (rule 6.3.1)
rules.1822: As for 1830. (rule 5.8.5)
rules.1824: As for 1830. (Rule XI, fourth section)
rules.1825: As for 1830; but a hex reserved for another company may not be laid on. (rule 4.2.8)
rules.1826: As for 1830; but a hex reserved for another company may not be laid on except with the permission of that other company. (page 15)
rules.1829: Only on the hex just vacated by the upgrading company's Survey Party, and then only if it is not occupied by a rival survey party. (rule 42.2) [ Some players ignore the survey parties in 1829, and play it by the same rule as for 1830.]
rules.1831: As for 1830 except that if it is a station tile, company must build a station.
rules.1832: As for 1830. (rule 6)
rules.1837: As for 1830. (rule V.3)
rules.1842: As for 1830, but not in Hamburg or Harburg. (rules 6.2, 1)
rules.1844: As for 1830.
rules.1846: As for 1830. (page 6)
rules.1847: As for 1830; in addition the Saarbr�cker Eisenbahn and Rhein-Nahe-Bahn may only place yellow tiles on light red hexes, while the Pfalzbahn companies may only place yellow tiles on light green hexes (actually blue in my copies).
rules.1850: As for 1830.
rules.1856: As for 1830. (pages 15, 16)
rules.1858: As for 1830. Private companies have notional tokens on each of their home hexes (rule 9.3).
rules.1859: After being laid, the tile must be reachable from one of the laying company's station markers by an arbitrarily large train, which can be a hex beyond cities fully occupied by other company tokens.
rules.1860: As for 1830.
rules.1861: As for 1830.
rules.1867: As for 1830. Certain hexes adjacent to Montreal and Toronto contain a yellow triangle at the edge of the hex. When laying a yellow tile in these hexes, it must connect to the yellow triangle.
rules.1870: As for 1830. (pages 19, 20)
rules.1873: After being laid, all track on the tile must be reachable from any of the laying company's station markers by an arbitrarily large train. Concession routes must not be blocked by the tile lay. Hexes that form part of the WBE concession route can only be built in phase 3 or later (rule 4.4.1).
rules.1880: As for 1830 (page 9) . In addition, the company must own a building permit valid for the current phase of the game.
rules.1881: As for 1830. In addition, tokens of the S-Bahn company and subnets do not block tram routes, and tokens of tramway companies for not block S-Bahn routes.
rules.1883: As for 1830.
rules.1891: As for 1830.
rules.2038: On hexes you 'explore' by moving a spaceship there and spending an extra movement point. (rule 7.11)
rules.18C2C: As for 1830.
rules.18NK: As for 1830.
rules.18NY: As for 1830.
rules.1822CA: As for 1830. (rule 5.8.7)
rules.1824 v2: As for 1830. (rule VII.6)
rules.1830 v1: After being laid, the tile must be reachable from one of the laying company's station markers by an arbitrarily large train. (rule 18.0)
rules.1830 v2: After being laid, the tile must be reachable from one of the laying company's station markers by an arbitrarily large train. (rule 7.2.1)
rules.1830 v3: After being laid, the tile must be reachable from one of the laying company's station markers by an arbitrarily large train. (rule 6.2.1)
rules.1830BC: New canals can be extended from any existing waterway.
rules.1847AE: As for 1830; in addition the Saarbr�cker Eisenbahn and Rhein-Nahe-Bahn may only place yellow tiles on light red hexes, the Pfalzbahn companies may only place yellow tiles on light blue hexes, while the Hessische Ludwigsbahn may only place yellow tiles on light green hexes.
rules.1862EA: As for 1830 (rule 7.6.1)
rules.1862EA v2: As for 1830 (rule 7.6.1)
rules.1865 Sardinia: As for 1830. (page 22)
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: As for 1830.

rules.18CLE: As for 1830. (rule 4.1)
rules.18CZ: As for 1830. (rule VIII.4)
rules.18EU: As for 1830; but a hex reserved for another company may not be laid on except with the permission of that other company. (page 12)
rules.18FL: As for 1830. (rule 7.2.1)
rules.18GB: As for 1830. (rule 5.3.2)
rules.18GL: As for 1830. (page 9)
rules.18GM: As for 1830. (page 38)
rules.18Ireland: For tiles that contain broad gauge track, at least one section of that track must be connected by broad gauge track to one of the company's station markers. If the tile consists entirely of narrow gauge track, that track must be connected by narrow gauge track to a station that is connected by broad gauge track to one of the company's stations markers.
rules.18Lilliput: After being laid, the tile must be reachable from one of the laying company's station markers by an arbitrarily large train. In addition, no city/metropolis may be laid adjacent to another (exception: starting tile and home cities), and no town/plain track may be laid adjacent to another.
rules.18Neb: As for 1830 (rule 4.5.2)
rules.18NW: As for 1830. (rule 4.3.1)

rules: 5.2 - Can you lay two tiles in a turn?

rules.1761: A second tile may be laid on payment of a fee of 10. Once the first 4 train has been purchased, a third tile may be laid for a further payment of 10.
rules.1812: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile operation may be performed, but only one of the two tile operations may be an upgrade. You may not lay a tile and upgrade it in the same turn.
rules.1817: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile operation may be performed, but only one of the two tile operations may be an upgrade. You may not lay a tile and upgrade it in the same turn.
rules.1822: From phase 3 onwards, a major company may lay two yellow tiles or upgrade one tile.
rules.1824: No.
rules.1825: Yes, if neither is an upgrade and they are not adjacent.
rules.1826: Yes, if neither is a upgrade and it is the company's first turn.
rules.1830: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1831: Yes. Four-fold by a company, seven-fold by a system.
rules.1832: Yes, if both are yellow. Systems may lay three yellow tiles or lay one yellow tile and upgrade another.
rules.1834: No, but using the special property of the Burbach Foundry private, an additional upgrade to a Luxembourg city may be carried out.
rules.1835: Only by major companies before first 3 train sold.
rules.1837: No.
rules.1841: Majors may do one tile lay or upgrade from each station-marker until a 3 train, then one from each up to a limit of 2 until a 5 train. But never more than one tile change on same hex.
rules.1842: Yes, but only on a share company's first OR, and not both on the same hex.
rules.1844: No.
rules.1846: Yes, each round a company may lay two yellow tiles or lay one yellow tile and upgrade one tile.
rules.1847: Yes, during the Yellow phase only.
rules.1848: Yes, once a 3 train has been sold. Two yellow tiles only.
rules.1850: Yes, if both are yellow and it is the company's first turn.
rules.1851: Yes, once a 3 train has been sold. Two yellow tiles only.
rules.1853: First four companies only. Each lay must be connected to a different station marker and the connecting routes must not use the same piece of track at any point.
rules.1856: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1857: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1858: Yes, for a fee of 20 (only 10 if all new track on one tile is narrow gauge). Both can be upgrades, but they must be in different hexes.
rules.1859: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1860: Yes if both are yellow and neither contains a large station.
rules.1861: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile operation may be performed, but only one of the two tile operations may be an upgrade. You may not lay a tile and upgrade it in the same turn.
rules.1862: Yes, once a 3 train has been sold. Two yellow tiles only.
rules.1867: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile operation may be performed, but only one of the two tile operations may be an upgrade. You may not lay a tile and upgrade it in the same turn.
rules.1868: Yes, a company may place or upgrade two track tiles at a cost of 10.
rules.1870: Yes, if both are yellow. Purchase of the MRBC by the MP or SSW can allow a third tile to be laid.
rules.1873: Concession routes are always built in one step, which can involve up to 5 tiles. For normal track lays and upgrades, two tiles can be placed if each tile is either yellow or a green tile with two completely separate sections of track.
rules.1880: Yes, once a 3 train has been sold, if both are yellow. The BCR may lay two yellow tiles from the start of the game. However, Foreign Investors only ever lay one tile in a turn.
rules.1881: Yes, tramway companies can place two yellow tiles in the Yellow phase.
rules.1883: Normally, no, but exceptions exist for the FSF and CCFR companies.
rules.1889: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1891: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1895: Yes, once an 8H train has been sold. Two yellow tiles only.
rules.1898: Majors may do one tile lay or upgrade from each station marker until a 3 train, then one from each up to a limit of 2 until end of turn. But never more than one tile change on same hex. Minors may do one tile lay or upgrade until a 4 train, then one from each station marker until end of game.
rules.1899: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.2038: Yes, multiple exploration allowed.
rules.1824 v2: No.
rules.18Scan: No.
rules.18VA: No.
rules.18USA: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile operation may be performed, but only one of the two tile operations may be an upgrade. You may not lay a tile and upgrade it in the same turn.
rules.1822CA: From phase 3 onwards, a major company may lay two yellow tiles or upgrade one tile.
For mid-west companies if both tiles are west of starting hex.
rules.1829 Mainline: You may lay any number of yellow tiles as long as the track laid is continuous. This continuous route can be traced through pre-printed track in a brown board hex. Track laying must finish if a connection is made to an existing city. It must also finish if a tile of types 3, 6, 7 or 115 is laid. If the Midland, NER or NBR need to lay a tile on their home hex when they frst operate, this lay is in addition to any other tile laying activities for that round.
rules.1830NL: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1869 USA West: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18AL: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18Chesapeake: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18EC: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18GA: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18GA v2: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18IN: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18Kaas: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: Only by using the special property of a private.
rules.1830BC: Yes, and more, depending on quality of digging team.
rules.1838 Rheinland: Only by major companies before first 3 train sold.
rules.1837SX: Yes, if there are sufficient building points and the build does not include the initial lay of a viaduct tile.
rules.18Neb: Yes, each round a company may lay two yellow tiles or lay one yellow tile and upgrade one tile.
rules.1847AE: Yes, throughout the Yellow phase, or if it is the company's first operating round.
rules.18BL: Yes, if both are yellow and it is the company's first turn.
rules.18CZ: Yes, if both are yellow and it is the company's first turn.
rules.1853 v2: First four companies only, and possible company 5 if it forms as a major company during the contract bidding stage. Each lay must be connected to a different station marker and the connecting routes must not use the same piece of track at any point. When they first operate, each of these companies must choose to either delay the ability to lay two tiles until Phase 3, or to gain the ability immediately. If the ability is gained immediately, the company must pay the bank every time that two tiles are laid. Company 1 must pay �50 to lay two tiles, companies 2 to 5 must pay �20 to lay two tiles.
rules.1862EA: Yes, if both are yellow and neither are N tiles.
rules.1862EA v2: Yes, if both are yellow and neither are N tiles.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile operation may be performed.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Yes. Companies may lay a number of tiles based on tile points. Each company has 3 tile points available. Most tile actions cost 1 point, but laying a yellow tile in a mountain hex or upgrading a city to russet or grey costs 2 points.
rules.18??: Yes, if both are yellow.
rules.18FL: Yes, if both are yellow.
rules.18NK: Yes, if both are yellow.
rules.18Africa: Up to four yellow track tiles as long as the track is continuous, or for the first turn of companies starting on double-city hexes, one green then three yellows. This continuous route can be traced through pre-printed track in a brown board hex. Track laying must finish if a connection is made to an existing city. It must also finish if a tile of types 3, 6, 7 or 115 is laid.
rules.18Ardennes: Yes, for public companies only. They may lay two yellow tiles or upgrade one tile.
rules.18C2C: Yes. Tiles are laid on a points basis. It is possible to lay up to four yellow tiles in one turn.
rules.18CLE: Yes. Companies may lay two yellow tiles during phase 2.
rules.18Dixie: Major companies normally lay up to two tiles each operating turn. All companies may lay one extra yellow tile on their first operating turn.
rules.18EU: Yes, for a minor company in its first OR.
rules.18GB: Yes, but at most one may be in a city. Both may be upgrades.
rules.18GL: Yes, for any company other than CONRAIL in its first OR.
rules.18GM: Yes. Two yellow tiles may be laid in clear terrain, two non-city track tiles may be upgraded to green or russet, or one each of these actions.
rules.18Ireland: Yes, on payment of a fee a second tile may be laid.
rules.18JP-T: Only by using the special property of a private or a major company.
rules.18Lilliput: Yes, by using the appropriate Action Card.
rules.18MS: Yes, a second yellow tile in its first OR.
rules.18NW: Yes, a second yellow tile in its first OR.
rules.18NY: Yes, either two tile lays or one tile lay and one upgrade, subject to sufficient funds being available.
rules.18NYC: All Lines may lay two yellow tiles in each operating round. In addition all Lines except the NYCTA may lay a third yellow tile in their first operating turn.
rules.18OE: Yes. Companies may lay a number of tiles based on available tile points. Different company types have different tile points available, and different tile types/actions cost different numbers of points.
rules.18Ruhr: Yes, either two yellow tiles or one yellow tile and one upgrade. You may not lay a tile and upgrade it in the same turn.
rules.18SA: No, except for companies that start operating in the Brown phase. These companies may lay/upgrade two tiles in their first operating turn.
rules.18SS: Yes, you may lay two tiles, lay one tile and upgrade another, or upgrade two tiles. You may not upgrade the tile just laid or upgraded with your second tile action.
rules.18SY-O: You may lay or upgrade one tile from each token a company has on the map. The same hex may be upgraded multiple times if the company has multiple tokens connected to that hex.
rules.18TN: Yes, if both are yellow. Ownership of private companies can allow additional tiles to be laid.
rules.18US: Yes, for Systems. Land Grant companies can lay up to three yellow tiles or lay two yellow tiles and upgrade one yellow tile to green if it can pay any required costs from its treasury.
rules.18West: Yes, for public companies. Land Grant companies can lay or upgrade up to three tiles (four tiles, up to two from each of its railheads, under the v2.3 retuned rules).
rules.Crisis: No, except that a green tile must be laid alongside a yellow one if available.
rules.Poseidon: There are no tiles in the game.
rules.Rolling Stock: There are no tiles in the game.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Yes, each round a company may lay two yellow tiles or lay one yellow tile and upgrade one tile, which can be the tile just laid.

rules: 5.4 - Do villages upgrade?

rules.1761: Yes, they stay as villages but acquire more connections.
rules.1800: Yes, they stay as villages but acquire more connections.
rules.1812: Yes, they stay as villages but acquire more connections.
rules.1817: Not applicable.
rules.1822: Yes, they stay as villages but acquire more connections.
rules.1824: Single villages upgrade, staying as villages but acquiring more connections. Double villages do not upgrade.
rules.1826: Yes, they stay as villages but acquire more connections.
rules.1831: Not applicable.
rules.1832: Single villages do, acquiring more connections and eventually scoring more. Double villages do not.
rules.1835: Yes, they stay as villages but acquire more connections.
rules.1837: Yes, single villages acquire bypasses, double villages coalesce.

rules: 6.1 - Cost of station markers

rules.1761: 0, then 10*hex distance. Distance measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1812: 0, then 20*hex distance, then 40*hex distance. Distance measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1817: All 0. They were paid for at flotation time: 5-share companies pay 50, 10-share companies pay 150 (total), for 3 tokens.
rules.1822: 0, then 100. Not applicable for destination tokens or exchange tokens.
rules.1826: 0, then 20*hex distance measured along route from nearest existing marker.
rules.1831: 40 for passenger station, 70 for freight yard until 5 train sold, then 70/110 until 9 train sold, then 110/210.
rules.1835: 0, then 20*hex distance from the original marker. Distance is measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1837: 0, then 20*hex distance, then 40*hex distance. Distance measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1841: All 0. They were paid for at flotation time: 50 each for historics, 25/50/100/200 depending on remoteness for non-historics.
rules.1842: 0, 3 * revenue of hex on which they are placed.
rules.1846: Normally 0, then 80. Some corporations have reserved city spots that cost 40. In the case of the B&O and PRR, the cost for these is 100 if there is no connection to the reserved city.
rules.1848: 0 for the home base, then 40, then 100 for any other tokens for most companies; Commonwealth Railways has two free home bases and three further tokens that cost 100 each.
rules.1851: 0; they were paid for (100 for 4) at flotation time.
rules.1853: 0 (for both home hexes, in some companies), 40, 100.
rules.1858: Free if from a Private company, twice the city value starting in phase 5, otherwise 40 per province (20 in the same province) from the nearest existing station marker
rules.1859: 40 in the yellow phase, 70 in the green phase, and 100 in the brown phase.
rules.1861: 0, then 20*hex distance, then 40*hex distance. Distance measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1867: 0, then 20*hex distance, then 40*hex distance. Distance measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1868: 20, 30, 40, 50, 60. These costs are havlved if placing a token in a city tile at the time it is placed or upgraded.
rules.1873: 0, then 100. 50 to buy an inactive marker from another company.
rules.1880: 0 for home bases, 40, 100, prices double when the first 8 train is sold.
rules.1881: 0 for home bases, 40, 80 ,120.
rules.1893: For the DE, RB and RSE, 0, 40, 100. For the AGV and HGK, which are formed by merger, 100.
rules.1898: All 0. They were paid for at flotation time: 50 each for historics, 25/50/100/200 depending on remoteness for non-historics.
rules.2038: Complex, but written on each company's card.
rules.18USA: All 0. They were paid for at flotation time: 5-share companies pay 50, 10-share companies pay 150 (total), for 3 tokens.
rules.1822CA: 0, then 100. Not applicable for destination tokens or exchange tokens.
rules.18FL: 0, then 20*hex distance measured along route from nearest existing marker.
rules.18NY: 0, then 20*hex distance measured along route from nearest existing marker.
rules.18US: 0, then 20*hex distance measured along route from nearest existing marker.
0, then whichever is greater of (20*rail distance to nearest existing station marker) or (value of city).
rules.Poseidon: No charge.
rules.1876-35: 0, then 20*hex distance from the original marker. Distance is measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1876-35 v2: 0, then 20*hex distance from the original marker. Distance is measured by 'a crow without a passport'.
rules.1837SX: 0, 60, 80 or 100 as indicated on the company charter. The cost varies between companies.
rules: 0, 60, 80 or 100 as indicated on the company charter. The cost varies between companies.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: 0, 60, 80 or 100 as indicated on the company charter. The cost varies between companies.
rules.18West: 0, then 100.
rules.1847AE: 0, then 60, 80, 100, except for the Hessische Ludgiwsbahn, which is 0 (two home stations), then 80, 100.
rules.1849v1&3: All 0. They were paid for at flotation time: first round start-ups pay 0, others pay 100 (total), for 3 tokens.
rules.1849v4: All 0. They were paid for at flotation time, according to the table in rule 3.3.
rules.1853 v2: 0 (for both home hexes, in some companies), 40, 100.
rules.1862EA: For Chartered Companies, �60 each for 3 tokens. For Non-chartered Companies, �40 each for 2 to 7 tokens. These costs are paid when the company is floated.
rules.1862EA v2: For Chartered Companies, �60 each for 3 tokens. For Non-chartered Companies, �40 each for 2 to 7 tokens. These costs are paid when the company is floated.
rules.1865 Sardinia: The cost depends on the terrain crossed at the borders of hexes along the route from any existing token to the new one.
rules.1869 The Golden West: 0, then 40, 100, but for companies with two home bases, it is 0/0 then 100.
rules.1869 USA West: 0, 40, 80, 120, 160. Most companies must add 100 to the cost if placing a token in Canada. On the other hand, the Canadian National Railroad and Canadian Pacific Railroad must add 100 to the cost if placing a token in the USA.
rules.18Ardennes: 40 for minor companies, 100 for public companies.
rules.18EU: All 0. 100 was paid for them at flotation time.
rules.18GB: 0, then 50.
rules.18GL: 0 (except for CONRAIL), then 20*rail distance to nearest existing station marker.
rules.18IN: 0, then 20*hex distance from the nearest token. Distance is measured by 'a crow without a passport'.

rules.18MW: 0, then 40+10*crow distance from the original marker.
