rules.18Ruhr: 0, 60, 80 or 100 as indicated on the company charter.
rules.Railroad Barons: No cost, but Operator tokens rather than station markers.

rules: 6.3 - Where can you lay a station marker?

rules.1829: It is laid by moving a survey party in the normal way to a city, and then changing its role.
rules.1831: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train. (Exception for C&O's second home base.)
rules.1835: , the newly-laid station marker must be connected by track to one belonging to that company; but this track may include one (arguably, more than one) sharp angle that would prevent a train from running over it: " Ein Fahrtrichtungswechsel ist hierbei erlaubt" . For 1837 the designer's intention was to allow no more than one backtrack.
rules.1837: , and in the first edition of
rules.1841: As well as the default rule below, the route must be from one of the laying company's existing non-mountain station markers, and must not cross an active border (not even twice).
rules.1846: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train, except for the B&O and PRR, which do not require any connection to lay a token in their reserved city spots.
rules.1853: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train, and must be within the company's 'patch'.
rules.1859: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train, which can be beyond cities fully occupied by other company tokens.
rules.1881: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train. An S-Bahn token on a minor hub station does not block routes of tramway companies. Tramway company tokens do not block routes of he S-Bahn company.
rules.2038: The newly-laid base, refuel, or claim must be reachable from one of the company's bases by a spaceship that it owns.
rules.1830 Cardgame: On the large gameboard in one of the token spaces for the company.
rules.1830BC: Waterworks may be built on any land other than that owned by player-owned privates; permission of the owner is required if land in player hands.
rules.1853 v2: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train, and must be within the company's 'patch'. After the first '5' train is bought, companies owning at least one '5' or '6' train may place a station marker at any station that they can reach from a home base using one of their trains. A company placing a station marker outside its 'patch' must include that station in one of its routes in the same operating round.
rules.18Ireland: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train using broad gauge track.
rules.18Scan: As well as the default rule below, station markers may be placed in off-board hexes with a free token space.
rules.Crisis: On a newly laid yellow station tile if this may be laid somewhere.
rules.Poseidon: On all hexes with white circles the ship touched in the turn.
rules.Rest: The newly-laid station marker must be reachable from one of the laying company's existing station markers by an arbitrarily large train.

The rules do not say when these are flipped over, but it is assumed this happens when the tramway companies float, because the rules do state that the base tokens for the S-Bahn main company and its three subnets are placed when the S-Bahn floats.

rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Contradictory. The sections on home bases and floating the company state that the token is placed at the start of the company's first operating turn, while the section of placing station markers says that the home bases were placed when the company was started.
rules.18??: When it first operates, except for any company started by the Grand Junction Investors private, which places its home station marker in Grand Junction when the private is bought.

rules: 7.1 - Can you run into a city completely filled by rival station markers?

rules.1831: Yes; but the company must pay current construction cost of those station-markers to owning company once per set of ORs.
rules.1873: No.
rules.1899: Yes, except for the station marker in Inner Mongolia, and the one in Port Arthur if approached across the sea.
Yes; but the company must then pay out half (rounded down) of the city value to the owner of one of the station-markers.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Not applicable. Revenue is generated from traffic chips and train points.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: Yes; except for the station markers in Minden, M�nster and Roermond, which block the associated off-board hexes.

rules:
7.2 - Can you do a run that passes through a city completely filled by
rival station markers?

rules.1831: Yes; but the company must pay current construction cost of those station-markers to owning company once per set of ORs.
rules.1859: Yes, by paying 10 to one of the companies with a token in the city. If one of those tokens belongs to a company not yet floated, the company running through may choose to pay the cost to that company, and make the payment to the bank.
rules.1860: One train may pass through a city completely filled by rival station markers.
rules.1870: A destination marker can be placed in a hex completely filled by rival station markers, and then allows runs through that hex.
rules.1873: Only on concession routes, but the city counts as 0 in that case.
rules.1881: No, except that S-Bahn tokens on minor hub stations do not block routes for tramway companies, and tramways company tokens do not block routes for the S-Bahn company.
rules.2038: Yes.
rules.1862EA: Not as standard, but several freight trains running end-to-end may run so that one of the train's runs stops at such a city and another starts again on the other side.
rules.1862EA v2: Not as standard, but several freight trains running end-to-end may run so that one of the train's runs stops at such a city and another starts again on the other side.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Not applicable. Revenue is generated from traffic chips and train points.
rules.18NK: A destination marker can be placed in a hex completely filled by rival station markers, and then allows runs through that hex.
rules.Poseidon: Yes.
rules.18US: Only if the company's or System's doubling token is in the city.
rules.18West: Only if it has a Bypass token in the city.
rules.Crisis: Only if it has a speculation token on the same tile.

rules: 7.3 - Unusual rules about running

rules.1761: 2+ and 3+ trains can include any number of villages which add to the value of the route. For 4, 5 and 6 trains, villages may be skipped.
rules.1812: Villages can be skipped. G-trains must run to a port and must have a mine on the route. If a company runs more than one G-train, each G-train must include a different mine on its route. A North-South bonus is payable if a train's route runs from a red off-board area marked N to a red off-board area marked S.
rules.1822: Local trains operate within a single city, although they may also run to a single small station. Trains with Pullmans attached count any number of small stations in addition to their limit of cities. E (Electric) trains may run on the same track as other trains, only stop at station tokens of the owning company and skip all other stations, and then double the total. The English Channel crossing hex does not count against the run of a train, nor does it earn revenue, but if not tokened by a company it provides access to France while there is an empty token space.
rules.1824: Only G (goods) trains can visit coal mines, which act as a terminus. The number on these train cards is the number of cities that the train may travel through. These trains may include any number of villages in their route. Income from coal mines is paid to the company treasury.
rules.1826: Some trains have run limits determined by counting hexes, not stations. Some trains ignore villages. Some trains count double revenue.
rules.1831: Has passenger and freight trains (and mixed trains up to 5). Also, train purchase comes before running, so trains bought from the bank may be used on their turn of purchase. (Trains bought from other companies may not.)
rules.1832: A route can only include the West Virginia Coal Fields if the operating company has a West Virginia Cola Fields token. The first time Miami is used in a run prior to the first '5' train being sold, it counts as zero.
rules.1834: 2T trains run from one city to another, counting all villages along the way towards their income, with one of the cities having its valued doubled. Trains may only run from one off-board area to another if running from a southern OBH to a northern OBH. If this is done the run gains a bonus of 20.
rules.1837: Coal trains visit and get paid for villages without restriction. Express trains ignore villages.
rules.1841: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction. Each route must include at least two places other than ports and passes. Each route must visit one of the company's own city-based tokens; those in mountain passes don't count for this.
rules.1842: At least one of a set of routes must include the company's starting place. Some tiles bear two values for the stations. The higher values are used if the company has a station marker on the tile.
rules.1844: The H trains count hexes not stations. Unlike H trains in other games, they include the hex where they start.
rules.1846: A route cannot run from one east off-board region to any other east off-board region. N/M trains can visit M cities and choose N of them to count as revenue, provided at least one of these contains one of the company's tokens. A route that connects an east off-board region to a west off-board region and counts both earns a bonus.
rules.1847: At least one of a set of routes must include the company's home station. Single train routes connecting selected off-board areas and/or cities gain a bonus.
rules.1848: Gauge change markers are placed on hex edges where the gauge of track changes. These markers count towards the length of a route as if they were value 0 cities. Plus-trains (e.g. 4+) can include one gauge change marker in addition to the usual length of its route. Visit and get paid for villages and small harbours without restriction. "e trains (The Ghan) do not count towards a company's train limit, nor does owning one satisfy the requirement for a company to own a train. A company may only own one 2E train. 2E trains cannot be traded between companies. A bonus is paid when the route of one train includes more than one K-city, the value of which increases with the number of K-cities in the run.
rules.1849: Routes are determined by counting hexes, not stations.
rules.1850: A route can only include the Mesabi Mining Range if the operating company has a Mesabi Range token. If an eligible company has a token placed in an edge area (a red off-board area with an appropriate token space), that area couints double for that company.
rules.1851: Red-to-red routes pay an extra 10 per stop (including 10 each for the two red OBHs).
rules.1853: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.1854: '+' trains visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.1858: M-trains run on narrow and duel gauge only; all others run on broad and dual gauge only. H-trains may run that many hexes (centre to centre); M-trains run that may large cities plus any number of small stations; E-trains must skip small stations; D-trains run as E-trains and double revenue. Ports and France count as large cities, not villages.
rules.1859: Trains may run through blocked cities by paying a fee to the company owning one of the blocking tokens.
rules.1860: All runs must intersect with each other, forming a coherent network, with at least one train visiting the company's home base. Halts may be bypassed or included as desired.
rules.1861: Villages can be skipped.
rules.1862: Some trains can skip cities. Some routes have destination bonuses.
rules.1867: Villages can be skipped.
rules.1870: Companies can make connection runs and place destination markers that double the value of the city if at the end of a route.
rules.1873: There are very special rules for routes and revenue calculation covered by rules 4.4.3 and 4.4.4 (1� pages of text).
rules.1879: Company starting locations have no value. If a company uses its starting location as part of a route, the value of the highest income town or city on the route is doubled.
rules.1881: The various S-Bahn subnets may not use track that another subnet has used in the same operating round. Bonus markers are placed around the edge of the map at the start of the game. The first tramway company to connect these marked hexes with a station in the city centre (marked with a red border) receives a bonus of 100. The bonus marker is then removed.
rules.1883: 2G trains can use routes already used by other trains.
rules.1889: Off-board area has a higher value for D-trains only.
rules.1895: Routes are determined by counting hexes, not stations. Mines pay directly to the company treasury and do not count to the revenue total.
rules.1898: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction. Each route must include at least two places other than ports and passes. Each route must visit one of the company's own city-based tokens; those in mountain passes don't count for this.
rules.1899: The Inner Mongolia off-board area increases in value with respect to the number of connections to the area a company can make. In addition, if a token is placed in this area, no other company may use it.
rules.2038: The 'train' is a spaceship. Each mine may only be worked once per OR.
rules.1822CA: Local trains operate within a single city, although they may also run to a single small station. Trains with Pullmans attached count up to twice the number of small stations in addition to their limit of cities. E (Electric) trains may run on the same track as other trains, only stop at station tokens of the owning company and skip all other stations, and then double the total. Trains with a grain private company attached count all stations except the small stations colocated with grain elevators, with count for income but not as stops.
rules.1824 v2: Only G (goods) trains can visit coal mines, which act as a terminus. The number on these train cards is the number of cities that the train may travel through. These trains may include any number of villages in their route. Income from coal mines is paid to the company treasury.
Run limits are determined by counting hexes, not stations. Winding mountain track counts double.
rules.1829 Mainline: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction, excluding Express trains. Some stations have a variable value that depends on other stations on the same route. The value of these stations is the highest value station elsewhere on the route, adjusted by the modifier for the variable station. If more than one variable station is included on a route, the lower value variable station is calculated first. If this then becomes the highest value station on the route, the next variable station is calculated from that value, and so on.
rules.1830BC: The single 'train' for all players is three separate floods of water coming down the rivers. Waterworks allow the owning player to divert the path of the water.
rules.1837SX: A train's number indicates the total track capacity for its route. One hex of single track has a capacity of two, one hex of double track has a capacity of one, off-board locations have various capacities. The total capacity of the track used on the route may not exceed the train's number. 6N trains may not enter grey hexes/tiles or red off-board locations. 16H trains may use only one track of a violet hexes, but may use several violet hexes.
rules.1838 Rheinland: Bonuses may be available for including a coal mine and/or a steel mill on a route. Bonuses are given for a route that runs from the off-board hexes in the north west to the south east, or from the north east to the south west.
rules.1847AE: Single train routes connecting selected off-board areas and/or cities gain a bonus.
rules.1853 v2: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.18EU: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.18GA: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.18Mex: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Visit and get paid for villages without restriction.
rules.1862EA: All runs must intersect with each other, forming a coherent network, with at least one train visiting the company's home base. There are three types of trains - Freight, Local and Express - each with their own rules about running. The company is required to own a permit for each type of train it uses. A train may not run to the London off-board area unless the company has placed a token in London.
rules.1862EA v2: All runs must intersect with each other, forming a coherent network, with at least one train visiting the company's home base. There are three types of trains - Freight, Local and Express - each with their own rules about running. The company is required to own a permit for each type of train it uses. A train may not run to the London off-board area unless the company has placed a token in London.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Revenue is generated from traffic chips and train points. Traffic chips are gained by companies from routes along which they have tokens, while traffic points come from the trains they own.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Some tiles have plus numbers on them representing classification yards. A train that includes one of these tiles and has a token on the tile receives a classification yard bonus, allowing it to extend the train's run by the plus amount (+1, +2 or +3).
rules.1869 USA West: Most companies have specific bonus routes that they can run for additional revenue.
rules.18NK: Companies can make connection runs and place destination markers that double the value of the city if at the end of a route.
rules.18??: Companies can make connection runs to off-board areas and place destination markers that double the value of the city if at the end of a route. Villages may be ignored, except for Oreburg.
rules.18Africa: Bonuses may be gained from a conecssion allocated to a company, and from running the Cape to Cairo and Dakar to Dar es Salaam transcontinental routes.
rules.18AL: Destination bonus when token placed on destination city. 4D trains count OBHs double.
rules.18Ardennes: 4D trains may reuse track used by a company's other train. If a train run an East-West and/or North-South Trans-Europ Express route, it gains a bonus of 30 for each station token on the route. This is doubled if both East-West and North-South routes are run at the same time.
rules.18BL: Rail buses (trams) may only include one city in their route, and may not run routes to red off-board areas. The grey pre-printed hex (P12) of the EHG (Eisenh�ttengesellschaft, private #4) may only be used on a route if the company possesses an appropriate Access Token.
rules.18C2C: Companies can make connection runs and place destination markers that double the value of the city if at the end of a route. Companies can also gain a one-time transcontinental bonus that moves their stock marker one space to the right on the stock market. They do this by running a train from any city on the west coast to any city east of the Mississippi river.
rules.18CLE: A route can include any number of villages, but may only include a number of cities up to the train number. Routes should start and stop at cities, but may stop at a village if the route can only include one city.
rules.18CZ: None.
rules.18EC: A company in possession of a mail contract may run a Mail Train in addition to its other trains.
rules.18FL: Trains other than the '3E' visit and get paid for villages without restriction. Hotels on oe of these routes pay a bonus. '3E' trains ignore villages and hotels completely.
rules.18GB: 4X, 5X and 6X trains must skip villages; they also gain a bonus for the distance between the start and end hexes of their route.
rules.18GL: Routes are determined by counting hexes, not stations. One of the three ferry lines may be active. An active ferry line can be used freely by the company with the ferry token, or by paying that company 50.
rules.18GM: Any value-added tokens on the route must be scored.
rules.18IN: an Interurban Traction (T) train can run for a total of three hexes and can use track used by another train in the same round.
rules.18Ireland: Trains may only run on broad gauge track. Narrow gauge track adds the value of small stations that are exclusively on narrow gauge track to the first broad gauge station they are connected to.
rules.18Kaas: The Ruhrgebied (J18 and K19) has no value by itself, it doubles the value of all other towns on the route, but counts as a town for route length. Alternative rules for this area are that it increases the value of all other towns on the route by 20 or 30.
rules.18Neb: If a train's route includes both an East and West off-board area the total value of one stop on the route is doubled.
rules.18NW: A train that runs between one of the eastern off-board locations and Alaska, Vancouver, Seattle or Portland adds 50 to the beginning and end locations.
rules.18NY: A company is not required to run for maximum possible earnings. Connection Bonus tokens may be claimed for routes that include the relevant hexes. Coal token may also be claimed. These tokens add 10 to the revenue for each subsequent round while the company owns them.
rules.18NYC: The Seacaucus Junction off-board location can only be run to if a Line either owns the PATH private or purchases a PATH token. The PATH private will not always be in play. If it is not, PATH tokens can be bought from the bank.
rules.18OE: Trains may be local or express trains. There are public and private ports, the latter requiring a token in the adjacent city. Trains may use these ports to make sea crossings.
rules.18PA: Four companies have tokens that double the value of their specified destinations. Bonus tokens may be purchased that add 40 to a company's overall revenue for running toor through Scranton (G12).
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: Bonuses may be available for including a coal mine and/or a steel mill on a route. Bonuses are given for a route that runs from the off-board hexes in the north west to the south east, or from the north east to the west.
rules.18SA: Trains may run through the off-board area of Patagonia. There are passenger trains and freight tokens and trains. A city fully tokened by one type of token may only be run to by the same type of train.
rules.18Scan: Express and high-speed trains ignore villages. You can only run to off-board hexes with a token space if the company occupies that space with one of its station markers.
rules.18SS: Tokens of other companies do not block or restrict a company's runs in any way. 8 trains may use track that other trains also use.
rules.18SY: -x trains can include an unlimited number of villages in their runs.
rules.18US: A train may run through a city fully occupied by blocking tokens if the company's or System's doubling token is in the city. An Express train that runs a coast-to-coast route applies a doubling bonus to any single city on its route. If the chosen city is already doubled by a x2 token, it is quadrupled. Freight trains earn the value of cities and junction towns that contain the company's or system's tokens. Freight bonuses that vary according to the phase are paid to companies that own classic trains (2, 3 or 4) or freight trains (2G, 3G or 4G).
rules.18USA: A train may only pass through each Rural Junction and each tile with a resource token once.
rules.18VA: The three different kinds of off-board area add various bonuses.
rules.18West: A train may run through a city fully occupied by blocking tokens if the company has a Bypass token in the city. Visit and get paid for villages without restriction (except 4D trains). Land Grant companies add grants to the revenue total for yellow tiles placed on certain hexes on the map. A train that runs a coast-to-coast route applies a doubling bonus to any single city on its route. If the chosen city is already doubled by a x2 token, it is quadrupled.
rules.Crisis: Routes are affected by signals, speculation tokens, etc.
rules.Poseidon: The nation's ship gains revenue from each temple and trading post owned by the netion that is visited. If the ship is not sent out a fixed sum, depending on the phase, is paid into the nation's coffers.
rules.Railroad Barons: Revenue is calculated from the Railroad Corporations (trains) owned, route network token income and bonuses given by Investors.
rules.Rolling Stock: Revenue is calculated from the income of subsidiary companies (i.e. private companies the public company has bought), plus their synergies, minus the cost of ownership.

rules: 7.5 - Is double-heading allowed?

rules.1825: Yes. Two 2 trains may be used as a 3 train.
rules.1829: Yes. An n train and an m train may be used as an n+1 train.
Yes. Two n trains may be used as a 2 n train.
rules.1862EA: Non-permanent freight trains must run end-to-end as a single freight run.
rules.1862EA v2: Non-permanent freight trains must run end-to-end as a single freight run.
rules.18OE: Yes, a major company may combine two or more non-permanent trains into one larger train.

rules: 8.1 - Does stock move right for payment of dividends?

rules.1761: Only if ten times the dividend per share equals or exceeds the current share price. For 10-share companies, is ten times the dividend per share equals or exceeds twice the current share price, the price increases by two places.
rules.1800: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1812: For Minor Companies, yes, although the share price may not exceed �150. For Public Companies, only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1817: One place if a dividend greater than or equal to the current share price, two places if greater than or equal to twice the current share price.
rules.1822: For Minor companies, yes. For Major Companies, only if the dividend is equal to or greater than the share price. If the dividend is equal to or greater than twice the share price, the share price moves two spaces to the right.
rules.1824: Yes.
rules.1825: One place if the total dividend is more than half the share price; two to four places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.1826: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1831: One place if all stakeholders paid; two places if all paid +200%.
rules.1832: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.1837: Right for 100% payout, right and down for 50% payout.
rules.1841: Only if earnings exceed the current price of a 10% share (20% for minors).
rules.1844: Yes; but regional companies may not move past the thin red line on the stock market.
rules.1846: One column if earnings are at least equal to the current share price, two columns if double, three columns if triple and the current share price is over $150.
rules.1849: Only if earnings exceed the current price of a 10% share (20% for minors).
rules.1850: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.1851: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1856: Yes.
rules.1858: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1859: Yes.
rules.1860: One place if the total dividend is equal to or greater than the share price; two to four places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.1861: Yes; for Minor companies, upwards instead if moving right of the yellow-shaded sixth column; for Public companies, only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1867: Yes; for Minor companies, their share price may not exceed 165; for Public companies, only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1870: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.1873: One place if the total dividend is more than half the share price; two to three places if the dividend is greater than two to three times the share price.
rules.1880: Yes.
rules.1881: Yes.
rules.1883: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.1891: Yes.
rules.1898: Only if earnings exceed the current price of a 10% share (20% for minors).
rules.2038: One place for half payout, two places for full payout.
rules.18EU: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18Neb: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18NY: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18OE: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18Ruhr: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18VA: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18West: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price.
rules.18FL: One place if a dividend greater than or equal to the current share price, two places if greater than or equal to twice the current share price.
rules.1822CA: For Minor companies, yes. For Major Companies, only if the dividend is equal to or greater than the share price. If the dividend is equal to or greater than twice the share price, the share price moves two spaces to the right.
rules.1824 v2: Yes.
rules: Yes.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Yes.
rules.18GM: Yes.
rules.Poseidon: Yes.
rules.1829 Mainline: One place if the total dividend is more than half the share price; two to four places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.18Africa: One place if the total dividend is more than half the share price; two to four places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.1830BC: One place per region of that terrain irrigated.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.18??: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.18EZ Level 3: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.18NK: Yes; and stays put for half payout.
rules.1853 v2: One place if the total dividend is less than twice the share price; two to five places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to five times the share price.
rules.1862EA: One place if the total dividend is equal to or greater than the share price; two to four places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.1862EA v2: One place if the total dividend is equal to or greater than the share price; two to four places if the dividend is equal to or greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.18Ardennes: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price. Minor companies and five-share companies whose dividend equals or exceeds twice the current share price move their tokens up two spaces. For minor companies in the grey zone, any non-zero dividend moves the price up to the 50 space.
rules.18BL: For a 100% dividend, yes. For a 75% dividend, only if the total dividend paid is equal to or higher than 150% of the current share price.
rules.18C2C: Yes; and stays put for half payout. If in the $500 space it is moved to the $250 space on the top row and is worth double the market value at the end of the game.
rules.18CZ: One place for small and medium companies, two places for large companies.
rules.18GB: At least one space for a non-zero dividend; two to four spaces if the dividend is greater than two to four times the share price.
rules.18GL: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price. Starting in phase 10H, if the dividend equals or exceeds the current share price, the price moves right two columns.
rules.18IN: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price. Starting in phase 6, if the dividend equals or exceeds twice the current share price, the price moves right two columns.
rules.18Ireland: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price. Additionaly, for 5-share companies only, if the dividend is at least twice the current share price, the token moves to the right one aextra space.
rules.18MW: Yes; except in blue zone, where 10% payout is needed to move one place, 30% two places.
rules.18NW: One column if earnings are at least equal to the current share price, from phase 6 onwards, two columns if double.
rules.18NYC: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price. Starting in phase 3E, if the dividend equals or exceeds twice the current share price, the price moves right two columns.
rules.18SA: Yes for a 100% payout, no for a 50% payout.
rules.18Scan: One column if earnings are at least equal to the current share price, two columns if double.
rules.18US: Only if the dividend paid out equals or exceeds the current share price. From phase 5E/4G, if a 10-share company delcares a dividend that equals or exceeds twice the current market value, it moves two spaces to the right.
rules.18USA: One to four steps if the total dividend is 50%, 100%, 150% or 200% of the share price.
rules.Rolling Stock: Share price movement is not directly coupled to dividends.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Prices move up rather than to the right. Only if the dividend paid out exceeds the current share price. If the dividend exceeds twice the current market value, it moves two spaces.

rules: 8.2 - What dividend payments go into the company's treasury?

rules.1761: None.
rules.1800: Those for shares in the company treasury.
rules.1812: Those for shares in the company treasury.
rules.1817: Those for shares in the company treasury.
rules.1822: For Minor Companies, 50%. For Major Companies, 50% (rounded up to the nearest 10) if paying a half dividend, or for shares in the company treasury.
rules.1824: None.
rules.1826: Those for unissued shares. But note that if a company floats after a certain phase it receives 100% capitalisation and unsold shares are issued into the bank pool.
rules.1830: Those for shares in the bank pool.

rules.1824 v2: None.

rules.1862EA: Those for shares in the company treasury.
rules.1862EA v2: Those for shares in the company treasury.

rules.1876-30 v2: Those for shares in the company treasury.

rules: 8.3 - Does stock move left for withheld earnings?

rules.1831: Left one place for withheld or paid preferred stock only, left two places for did not run a train.
rules.1846: Yes, if there is no payout or payout is less than half its current share price.
rules.1853: Yes, if shares of the company are in the bank pool.
rules.1870: Yes, but for a withheld connection run the price does not change.
rules.1830BC: No; a waterwork of the lowest value is removed instead.
rules.18NY: Yes, if there is no payout or payout is less than half its current share price.
rules.1853 v2: Yes, if shares of the company are in the bank pool.
rules.1865 Sardinia: No. It does move left, however, if a zero dividend is declared.
rules.18??: Yes, but for a withheld connection run the price does not change.
rules.18NK: Yes, but for a withheld connection run the price does not change.
rules.18TN: Yes, except for companies that own one train when the effects of Civil War are applied, in which case the stock price remains the same.
rules.Poseidon: No.
rules.Rolling Stock: Share price movement is not directly coupled to dividends.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Prices move down rather than to the left. Yes.

rules: 8.4 - Can a company make a partial payout?

rules.1761: It may make a 50% payout. Odd units are rounded in favour of the shareholders.
rules.1800: It may make a 50% payout. Odd units are rounded in favour of the shareholder. The amount paid out to the shareholders determines whether its share price moves to the right.
rules.1812: It may make a 50% payout. Odd units are rounded in favour of the shareholder. The amount paid out to the shareholders determines whether its share price moves to the right.
rules.1817: It may make a 50% payout. Odd units are rounded in favour of the shareholders.
rules.1822: For Minor Companies, 50% is standard. For Major Companies, a 50% payout is allowed (rounded up to the nearest 10).
rules.1824: Pre-Staatsbahnen companies pay half their income to their owners and half to their treasury.
rules.1826: It may make a 50% payout. Odd units are rounded in favour of the shareholder. The amount paid out to the shareholders determines whether its share price moves to the right.
rules.1831: It may pay preferred 50%, common 25%, withhold 25%, stock price does not move.
rules.1832: It may make a 50% payout. Odd units are rounded in favour of the shareholders.
rules.1837: It may make a 50% payout. Amounts are calculated exactly, then odd half-crowns rounded in favour of the bank.

rules.1844: No.

If this makes the payment of dividends for individual 10% share difficult, the shareholder dividend is reduced by 5 and this amount added to the company treasury (e.g. a dividend of 90 would result in a shareholder dividend of 45, making payment of 4� per share problematic, so the shareholder dividend would be reduced to 40 and the deducted 5 added to the company treasury).
rules.Rolling Stock: The President freely sets a dividend per share within a range from zero to one third of the share price.

rules: 9.1 - Can companies buy trains from one another?

rules.1761: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1812: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1817: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1822: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1824: Yes, once a 3 train has been purchased, minimum price 1 if both companies have the same Director, face value otherwise.
rules.1825: Yes, minimum price 10. For Unit 1 and Unit 2 the smallest company credit note is 10, so the price must be a multiple of 10. When playing with Unit 3 the smallest company credit note is 1, making the price any value of 10 or more.
rules.1826: Yes, minimum price 1, once a 6H train has been bought. The Etat and SNCF can only trade at face value. Companies with loans can only buy at face value or less, or sell for face value or more.
rules.1831: Yes, minimum price 1, maximum face value.
rules.1832: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1834: Yes, minimum price 1 if they have the same President, unrestricted otherwise. (Most people play minimum price 1 always.)
rules.1835: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1837: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1841: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1842: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1844: Yes. But if they have different Presidents, or if one of them is the SBB, then only at face value.
rules.1846: Yes, minimum price 1, but phased-out trains may not be purchased.
rules.1847: Once a 4 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1848: Yes, once a 3 train has been purchased, minimum price 1 if both companies have the same Director, face value otherwise.
rules.1850: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1851: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1854: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1856: Yes. CGR only buys and sells at face value, and cannot buy non-permanent trains. Other trades, minimum price 1.
rules.1857: Yes, minimum price 1 if they have the same President, unrestricted otherwise. (Most people play minimum price 1 always.)
rules.1858: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1859: Yes, minimum price 1 if they have the same President, unrestricted otherwise. (Most people play minimum price 1 always.)
rules.1860: Yes, minimum price 10. Note, however, that this is not allowed if the buying company already has a train and the selling company has only one train.
rules.1861: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1867: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1868: Yes, minimum price 1 if they have the same President, unrestricted otherwise. (Most people play minimum price 1 always.)
rules.1870: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1873: Yes, minimum price 1, maximum price double face value. Machines cannot be traded. The last standard train of a company cannot be bought. The applicable maintenance cost has to be paid for trains being traded.
rules.1879: Yes, minimum price 1 if they have the same President, unrestricted otherwise. (Most people play minimum price 1 always.)
rules.1880: Yes, once a 3 tain has been bought, minimum price 1, but only if the two companies have the same Director.
rules.1881: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1883: Yes, minimum price 1.
rules.1891: Yes. JNR only buys and sells at face value, and cannot buy non-permanent trains. Other trades, minimum price 1.
rules.1893: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1895: Yes, minimum price 1, but only if the two companies have the same President.
rules.1898: Once a 3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.1899: Yes, minimum price 1 if they have the same President, unrestricted otherwise. (Most people play minimum price 1 always.)
rules.2038: Yes, once a 6/2,4/3 spaceship has been sold. The Asteroid League's last spaceship cannot be bought from it. Minimum price 1.

rules.1869 The Golden Spike: Yes, minimum price 1.

rules.1847AE: Once a 3+3 train has been bought, minimum price 1.

rules.1862EA v2: Yes, at face value only for trains in the currently available band. For older trains, the price is set at half face value.
rules.18MW: Yes, minimum price 1, but only if the two companies have the same President.
rules.18BL: Yes, once the first 3 train or SB3 rail bus has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.18CZ: Yes, once the first b-train has been bought, minimum price 1.
rules.18Dixie: Yes, minimum price 1, except for the SCL/IGC, which may only buy or sell trains at face value.
rules.18GB: Yes, minimum price 1. Note, however, that this is not allowed if the buying company already has a train and the selling company has only one train.
rules.18GL: Yes, minimum price 1, once a 6H has been bought. CONRAIL may only buy and sell at face value. Companies with loans can only buy at face value or less, or sell for face value or more.
rules.18IN: Yes, minimum price 1. This applies to trains bought between similar types of companies. All train purchases between minor and major companies is at face value.
rules.18Mex: Yes, miimum price 1, except for the NdM, which may only buy or sell trains at face value.
rules.18Neb: Yes, minimum price 1, but only if the two companies have the same President, and no more than face value if the President is assisting with the purchase.
rules.18NW: Yes, once a 3 train has been purchased, minimum price 1, but only from a company of the same type. For example, 10-share companies may not buy trains from 5-share companies or privates.
rules.18NY: Yes, minimum price 1. However, if either company has a loan, trains must be purchased at face value.
rules.18NYC: Yes, minimum price 1. However, minor companies may not buy trains from Lines amd vice versa, and the NYCTA may only buy and sell trains at face value.
rules.18OE: Once the Major RR Phase has begun, minimum purchase price 1, except for Pullmans, which must be bought for 75.
rules.18Scan: Yes, minimum price 1. If the company has no credit the President may use his cash on hand to make the purchase, but may not sell stock to raise more cash.
rules.Poseidon: Yes, after the first 4 ship is sold.
rules.Railroad Barons: Yes, minimum price 1 (referring to Railroad Corporations).

rules: 9.2 - Must a major share company buy a train if it does not have one?

rules.1761: No.
rules.1812: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it cannot buy a train, even by taking out loans, its price on the stock market is moved one space down.
rules.1817: No, but if it ends its operating turn without a train, it will be liquidated.
rules.1822: Yes.
rules.1824: Yes.
rules.1826: Yes.
rules.1831: Yes. And systems must have two or three trains, depending on number of companies that merged.
rules.1832: If it has a route.
rules.1837: Yes.
rules.1841: If it has a route.
rules.1842: Yes. And if a private company has no train and does not buy one, it will have to be auctioned off at the start of the next OR.
rules.1844: Major companies and regional companies must if they have a route, pre-SBB companies need not.
rules.1846: Yes.
rules.1848: Yes, if it has a route, even if the company owns a 2E train.
rules.1850: If it has a route.
rules.1853: No; but its Director may choose to make up the balance from his own money if the company has insufficient credit for a train, leaving the company with an empty treasury.
rules.1856: If it has a route.
rules.1858: No, but the stock price moves to the left if it does not own a train at the end of an operating round.
rules.1859: If it has a route.
rules.1860: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it cannot buy a train and has a route it is declared
rules.1861: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it cannot buy a train it is nationalised and becomes part of the Russian State Railway.
rules.1867: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it cannot buy a train it is nationalised and becomes part of the Russian State Railway.
rules.1870: If it has a route.
rules.1873: Yes. It must buy a standard train when it operates for the first time. The rules ensure that it will never be without a standard train at any later point of the game.
rules.1880: Yes.
rules.1881: Yes, while there are new trains available.
rules.1883: If it has a route.
rules.1891: If it has a route.
rules.1898: If it has a route.
rules.2038: Yes.
rules.18USA: No, but if it ends its operating turn without a train, it will be liquidated.
rules.1822CA: Yes.
rules.1824 v2: Yes.

rules.18MS: If it has a route, and there is at least one train in the initial offering or bank pool.

rules.18GB: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it cannot buy a train and has a route it is declared
rules.insolvent: and must lease a train from the bank, retaining dividends, until it is able to buy a train.
rules.1862EA: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it is unable to buy a train the company goes bankrupt.
rules.1862EA v2: Yes, if it is able to do so. If it is unable to buy a train the company goes bankrupt.
rules.1865 Sardinia: If it has one or more traffic chips.
rules.1876 v2: Yes, by a 'forced assisted train purchase'.
rules.18US: A 4-share Eastern company, 10-share company or System must own a train if it has operated in the current round. 5-share Land Grant companies and the DRG are not required to own a train.
rules.18West: Yes, if it is a public company. Granger Road and Land Grant companies do not need to own a train.
rules.Crisis: If it could run a train (type I companies can run trains as 1 trains).

rules: 9.3 - Can trains be sold back to the bank?

rules.1812: Yes, in phases 5 and 6 only, receiving one quarter of its original cost rounded down as a trade-in against the cost of another train from the bank or bank pool. Traded-in trains go into the bank pool.
rules.1824: No, but one train per company per round can be traded in at 50% of face value for the next most powerful type. Traded in trains are removed from the game.
rules.1837: No, but if at the train limit, it can pay half a train's cost to put it back in the bank, so long as it then buys a train.
rules.1858: No, but wounded trains may be discarded.
rules.1873: No, but trains may be scrapped for no cost. Scrapped trains are removed from the game.
rules.1893: No, but one train per company per round can be traded in at 50% of face value for the next most powerful type. Traded in trains are placed in the bank pool.
rules.1824 v2: No, but one train per company per round can be traded in at 50% of face value for the next most powerful type. Traded in trains are removed from the game.
rules.1829 Mainline: Yes, �180 is paid by the bank for any train, which is then available from the bank at full price.
rules.1869 USA West: No, but trains may be voluntarily returned to the bank without compensation.
rules.18??: The company owning the Franklin Imports & Exports private may sell two trains per game for 40% of their cost, or one train per game for 60% of its cost.
rules.18CZ: No, but during an Acquisition, trains of the smaller company may be scrapped voluntarily.
rules.18EU: No, but Pullmans may be returned to the bank at any time for no recompense.
rules.18Ireland: No, but in phases 10 and D, a company may trade in one of its existing trains for a new train, paying the difference between the cost of the two trains.
rules.18Lilliput: No, but obsolete trains may be returned voluntarily to the bank and placed in the train pool.
rules.18NY: Trains may be voluntarily scrapped for one quarter of their full cost. A company's last train may only be scrapped if the company may then buy a new train without resorting to loans or emergency fund raising.
rules.Poseidon: With the purchase of an E ship, other ships can be traded in for half their value against the cost of an E ship.

rules:
9.4 - When a company is forced to buy a train and cannot buy one with its
own means, what train may it then buy?

rules.1761: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1800: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1812: A company must attempt to buy a train if possible, but if it cannot afford to do so, even by taking out loans, it does not have to do so.
rules.1817: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1822: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool. For double-sided trains, the cheaper version must be the one purchased. When buying a train from another company, the director may not contribute any of his own money, so the company must be able to afford this without assistance.
rules.1824: Any available train from the bank or offered by other companies. A clarification from Lonny Orgler states that the company can choose any of these trains - if the company has insufficient money for the chosen train, the Director can add the necessary funds.
rules.1825: A company does not have to own a train. However, a company in receivership must buy a train as soon as funds permit unless there is no route on which it can run. While not stated, this is assumed to be from the bank.
rules.1826: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or starting in phase 6H, from another company at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.1829: A company does not have to own a train. However, a company in receivership must buy a train as soon as funds permit unless there is no route on which it can run. While not stated, this is assumed to be from the bank.
rules.1831: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.1835: Any second-hand train (from the bank pool or another company) or the cheapest new train (only one type can be available at a time). This is what the German rules say. (One English translation says the cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.)
rules.1837: You can buy any available train: you may pay any agreed amount for a train from another company; you may buy any train in the bank pool; you may buy any available new train (there is typically a choice of two).
rules.1844: Any train from the bank; or any train from another company wishing to sell, at not more than face value.
rules.1846: A currently available train from the bank. If it can afford one of current types but not the other, or can afford a second hand train, after issuing shares, the President may not add more cash to buy a more expensive train.
rules.1848: The next new train from the bank.
rules.1851: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool. The President of the selling company makes the deal after any necessary share sales.
rules.1853: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1854: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.1858: Any train from the bank or bank pool, not necessarily the cheapest. If the company has funds remaining after the purchase it can use these funds to buy any train from any source.
rules.1859: As for 1830.
rules.1860: Not applicable. The company leases the smallest train from the new trains or the bank pool.
rules.1862: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.1867: Its choice of train from the bank or bank pool that it can afford with company credit plus any loans it is able to take out.
rules.1870: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.1873: There is no fund raising procedure to buy the mandatory train. COmpanies go bankrupt if they cannot buy the train with their own means, followed by receivership.
rules.1880: Any train available from the bank, but not a restored 2 train.
rules.1881: Any available train from the bank or the bank pool.
rules.1883: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.1893: The cheapest new train from the bank, or any train from the bank pool.
rules.1895: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company with the same president for at least 1.
rules.1898: The cheapest train available in the bank, or a train from another company at an agreed price not exceeding its face value. The President of the selling company makes the deal before any necessary share sales.
rules.2038: The cheapest spaceship type must be bought from the bank or bank pool. If the President is helping she can freely choose between a Scout and a Tug of the same type .
rules.1829 Mainline: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1830 Cardgame: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1853 v2: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1869 USA West: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.18Africa: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.18EZ Level 1: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.18USA: A company does not have to own a train.
rules.1822CA: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool. For double-sided trains, the cheaper version must be the one purchased. When buying a train from another company, the director may not contribute any of his own money, so the company must be able to afford this without assistance.
rules.1824 v2: Any available train from the bank or from another company.
rules.18AL: Any available train from the bank or from another company.
rules: You may be compelled to take out a loan to assist with the purchase of a train from the bank.
rules.1830 v1: Avalon Hill PC program: As in 1898.
rules.or: a train from another company at an agreed price not exceeding its face value. The President of the selling company makes the deal simultaneously with any necessary share sales (this has been interpreted as meaning that the old and new President must both agree to the deal; and in other ways).
rules.1830 v2: The cheapest train available in the bank or the bank pool. If the company and the president do not have enough available cash between them, the bank pays the difference and the company goes into receivership.
rules.1830 v3: The cheapest train available in the bank, or a train from another company at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.1830BC: The cheapest train available in the bank.
rules.18VA: The cheapest train available in the bank.
rules.18EC: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.18NL: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.18Ruhr: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value.
rules.1876-35: Any second-hand train (from the bank pool or another company) or the cheapest new train (only one type can be available at a time). This is what the German rules say. (One English translation says the cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.)
rules.1838 Rheinland: Any second-hand train (from the bank pool or another company) or the cheapest new train (only one type can be available at a time).
rules.18FL: Any train from the bank; or any train from another company wishing to sell, at not more than face value.
rules.1847AE: A train from the bank. The rules do not say whether this includes the bank pool.
rules.1876-35 v2: A train from the bank. The rules do not say whether this includes the bank pool.
rules.1862EA: The next new train from the bank.
rules.1862EA v2: The next new train from the bank.
rules.Poseidon: The next new train from the bank.
rules.18GB: Not applicable. The company leases the smallest train from the new trains or the bank pool.
rules.1861 v1: Its choice of train from the bank or bank pool that it can afford with company credit plus any loans it is able to take out. This is a clarification from Markus Welborune/Mike Hutton.
rules.1861 v2: Its choice of train from the bank or bank pool that it can afford with company credit plus any loans it is able to take out.
rules.1865 Sardinia: Any available train from the bank or the bank pool.
rules.18Dixie: Any available train from the bank or the bank pool.
rules.18MS: Any available train from the bank or the bank pool.
rules.18PA: Any available train from the bank or the bank pool.
rules.18SA: Any available train from the bank or the bank pool.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.1876-30 v2: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18??: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18GA: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18GA v2: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18GM: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: The cheapest new train from the bank, or any train from the bank pool.
rules.18Ardennes: The next train in the bank. The company may use Emergency Money Raising to buy a more expensive train from the bank even if it can afford a cheaper train that is available from the bank.
rules.18BL: The cheapest train or rail bus (tram) in the available boxes, or the cheapest train or rail bus (tram) in the bank pool.
rules.18Chesapeake: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool, or a train from another company for up to face value.
rules.18CLE: Not stated. Assumed to be the cheapest train in the bank or bank pool.
rules.18CZ: Any available from the bank or bank pool. The Director may not sell shares to raise funds. If more cash is needed than they have, the difference must be borrowed from the bank.
rules.18EZ Levels 2 and 3: The cheapest train from the bank or the bank pool, or from another company for a price below the cheapest bank or bank pool train.
rules.18IN: Any train from the bank or bank pool. However, if it is required to take loans to buy a train, it must then buy the cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18Ireland: Any train from the bank or bank pool, or a train from another company.
rules.18Lilliput: A company does not have to own a train, but if it wants to purchase one the Director can make up the difference from private assets, leaving the company treasury at zero.
rules.18MW: The cheapest train available in the bank, or a train from another company with the same President at a price not exceeding face value.
rules.18Neb: Any currently available train in the bank, or a train from another company controlled by the same President. The company may use Emergency Money Raising to buy a more expensive train from the bank even if it can afford a cheaper train that is available from the bank.
rules.18NW: A company unable to buy a train must take the minimum loan from the North American Bank to buy the cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18NY: The cheapest train from the bank or bank pool if loans were used or the President contributed funds. If money was rised purely by selling treasury shares, then any train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18NYC: Any train from the bank or bank pool. However, if it is required to take loans to buy a train, it must then buy the cheapest train from the bank or bank pool.
rules.18OE: The cheapest, un-rusted train in the the Locomotive Works or the bank pool.
rules.18Scan: Any available train from the bank or bank pool, or from another company, at an agreed price not exceeding its face value. However, stock may not be sold to raise additional cash if buying a train from another company.
rules.18US: The next train available from the bank. If more than one type is available, the President may choose which one to buy, even if this then requires him to provide additional funds that would not be required for another available train.
rules.18West: The next train available from the bank. If more than one type is available, the President may choose which one to buy, even if this then requires him to provide additional funds that would not be required for another available train.
rules.Crisis: The company goes into 'receivership', a complex process.
rules.Railroad Barons: A company does not have to own a train (referring to Railroad Corporations).
rules.Steam Over Holland: The cheapest available train. The president does not have to accept an offer from another president to buy a train from that company.
rules.Rest: The cheapest train available in the bank or bank pool. Thus a company may be compelled to buy a used train.

rules: 9.5 - Must a minor company buy a train if it does not have one?

rules.1761: No.
rules.1812: A company must attempt to buy a train if possible, but if it cannot afford to do so, even by taking out loans, it does not have to do so.
rules.1822: Yes.
rules.1824: Yes. Minor companies in 1824 are the Coal Railways and the pre-Staatsbahnen companies.
rules.1837: No.
rules.1841: Yes.
rules.1844: No.
rules.1861: Yes.
rules.1867: Yes.
rules.1880: No. Consider Foreign Investors to be minor companies in 1880. They lease a train from the bank rather than buying one.
rules.1898: Yes.
rules.2038: No, but after the Asteroid League is formed, if it does not have one or buy one, it must merge into the Asteroid League. The President may not contribute money.
rules.18EU: No.
rules.18NY: No.
rules.18NYC: No.
rules.18Scan: No.
rules.1822CA: Yes.
rules.18IN: Yes.
rules.1824 V2: Usually. Minor companies in 1824 are the Coal Railways and the pre-Staatsbahnen companies. However, if a Coal Railway has to buy a train but no G train is available from the bank, the Coal Railway does not need to buy a train.
rules.1865 Sardinia: If it has one or more traffic chips.
rules.18Neb: Yes, if it has a route. Local Companies may only own rusted trains, which are permanent for these companies.
rules.18OE: It must buy its reserved 2+2 train in its first operating turn, unless Train Phase 4 has begun.

rules:
9.6 - Can trains of the final type be purchased as soon as one train of
the next-to-last type is purchased?

rules.1812: Yes.
rules.1854: The Orient Express trains are available as soon as the 6 trains run out.
rules.1856: Yes.
rules.1858: 5D trains become available once the first 7E/6M train has been bought.
rules.1859: Yes.
rules.1861: 5+5E trains become available once the first 8 train has been bought. 2+2 trains are also available if in play.
rules.1867: 5+5E trains become available once the first 8 train has been bought. 2+2 trains are also available if in play.
rules.1873: Diesel railcars may be bought once the first set of 3 ORs has started in phase 5, which is triggered by buying the first 5 train or 5 machine.
rules.1891: Yes.
rules.2038: Yes.
rules: Yes.
rules.18GM: Yes.
rules.18IN: Yes.
rules.18Neb: Yes.
rules.18NW: Yes.
rules.18VA: Yes.
rules.18West: Yes.
rules.1829 Mainline: Yes, 4Ts and 2+2s are available once the first 4+4E has been bought.
rules.1830 v3: Yes. This is stated in rule 6.6, but has been omitted from the Phase table on page 27, despite attempts to persuade them to include it.
rules.1869 USA West: 4E trains become available once the first 5 train has been bought. All remaining trains (5E, 7 and 8) become available once the first 6 train has been bought.
rules.18Africa: Once the last 4E train is purchased, all remaining trains become available.
rules.18Dixie: Yes, indeed, once a 7+3 train is purchased, which is the second-to-last type.
rules.18MS: Yes, indeed, once a 7+3 train is purchased, which is the second-to-last type.
rules.18GB: 5X trains become available after the first 4X; 6X trains become available after the first 5X.
rules.18OE: Level 8 trains become available once the first four level 7 trains have been purchased.
rules.18Rhl Rhineland: 6 trains become available when the first 5 train has been bought. The Rheingold-Express (8 trains) become available when the first 6 train has been bought.
rules.18Scan: Yes, 5Es are available when the first 5 is bought, and 4Ds are available when the first 5E is bought.

rules.1862EA v2: Not applicable (no private companies).
rules.18EU: Not applicable (no private companies).

rules.1837SX: Yes, at any agreed price, in the buyer's or seller's turn in a stock round.

rules.1880: No.

rules.Rolling Stock: As soon as share companies exist in the price range shown on the private company certificate, and always at maximum price if bought from the foreign investor. Private companies may be bought from players, the foreign investor, or other share companies.
