rules.18NK: Only the A-OO and B-MKO privates.
rules.18NL: Only the DV, and the HSM and SZB when they buy their first trains.
rules.18NW: Some, as noted in the rules.
rules.18NY: P1, P2 and P3, yes. P6 closes when the D&H buys a train.
rules.18NYC: Only the Pennsylvania Steel Company, Steinway Tunnel Company and City Hall Station Company.
rules.18Ruhr: The two Pfederbahn private companies close if used to establish a railway link for a private Montan Company.
rules.18SA: The FN closes when the ENFER buys its first train.
rules.18Scan: The Mine when the bonus token is bought, and the SJ when the DSB buys its first train.
rules.18SS: Privates A, B and C close when their special properties are used. Privates D, E and F close when the Yuu, Ai and Ha Railways respectively purchase their first trains.
rules.18SY: Privates A, B, C and D.
rules.Poseidon: Yes, except for P4 (Poseidon).
rules.Steam Over Holland: Only the SWA, KKvI and RW.

rules: 10.5 - When do private companies close?

rules.1761: Stagecoach private companies close when used, or when a rail connection exists between the two named cities. The Foss Dyke Canal private company closes when the first 5 train is purchased.
rules.1812: First 5 train, except for private companies #11 and #12, which are permanent.
rules.1817: Never.
rules.1822: With the exception of private company #15, which must close at the start of phase 7 but may be closed earlier, private companies are not forced to close. However, some are removed from play when taken by a minor or major company, when they give the acquiring company the associated token(s) or assets.
rules.1824: When exchanged for a share in one of the Regional Railways (referring to Mountain Railways).
rules.1826: First 10H train, but the mail +1 and train limit +1 tokens last until an E train is sold.
rules.1829: At the start of phase four. In the standard game this is when the first 7 train is bought. When playing with the additional trains from kit MSK2 this is when the first 6 train is bought. If using the optional PC rule, private companies in the bank pool close when a tile is laid on their home hex (or either hex for the L&M).
rules.1831: Not applicable.
rules.1832: First 5 train.
rules.1837: First 5 train.
rules.1841: First 4 train.
rules.1842: Auctioned off at start of next OR after sale of first 5 train.
rules.1844: First 5 train or 5H train.
rules.1846: Phase III.
rules.1850: Some or all close when the first 5 train is bought, some may survive until the first 6 train is bought.
rules.1854: Moutain railways close on first 5 train. Local railways may close, merge, or continue.
rules.1856: First 5 train, but the bridge and tunnel tokens are permanent, and the port token lasts until the first 6 train.
rules.1857: Yes, but some only close if owned by players, while some only close if owned by companies.
rules.1858: Either after the earnings phase of a share company, or during the final exchange round. In all cases they are exchanged for face value in cash from the bank.
rules.1859: First 5 train.
rules.1860: When exchanged for 10% shares in their associated companies, or when the Fishbourne Ferry Company is purchased.
rules.1861: Never - they are nationalised when the first 6 train is bought and become part of the Russian State Railway.
rules.1862: At any time when their owners choose to close them.
rules.1867: Never - they are nationalised when the first 6 train is bought and become part of the Russian State Railway.
rules.1870: First 5 train, but the port and cattle tokens last to the first 6 train.
rules.1873: When they are not bought in the initial auction round, or when an owning player chooses to close them. Closed mining private companies can later be bought and thereby revived by mining share companies.
rules.1880: Never. However, they stop paying their fixed income once the first 4 train is bought.
rules.1881: Not applicable.
rules.1883: First 5 train, but may occur earlier if the SEFTA is created through merger.
rules.1889: First 5 train, except player's Uno-Takamatsu Ferry. Its revenue becomes 50, but may not be sold thereafter.
rules.1891: First 5 train, but the Yamaguchi Prefectural Tramline and Chugoku Railway tokens are permanent.
rules.1893: For the FsSD, when exchanged for RB certificates, or when forced to do this after the first 5 train is bought. For the EVA, when the first 6 train is bought. For the HdSK, when the merger of the HGK takes place.
rules.1898: First 4 train.
rules.2038: Phase V.
rules: First 5 train.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: First 5 train.
rules.18??: First 5 train.
rules.18FL: First 5 train.
rules.18GM: First 5 train.
rules.18Scan: First 5 train.
rules.Steam Over Holland: First 5 train.
rules.18USA: Never.
rules.18VA: Never.
rules.1822CA: With the exception of private companies #8 and #9, which must close at the start of phase 7 but may be closed earlier, private companies are not forced to close. However, some are removed from play when taken by a minor or major company, when they give the acquiring company the associated token(s) or assets.
rules.1824 v2: When exchanged for a share in one of the Regional Railways (referring to Mountain Railways).
rules.1862EA: Not applicable.
rules.1862EA v2: Not applicable.
rules.18US: Not applicable.
rules.18West: Not applicable.
rules.18GL: First 10H train.
rules.18NW: First 6 train.
rules.1865 Sardinia: First 5 train if in player hands, never once transferred to a public company.
rules.18C2C: First 5 train, but the cattle, coal, fish, gold, labor, lumber and port tokens last until the first 6 train. Engineer tokens stay active until the end of the game.
rules.18CLE: First 6 train, except for the ANS, which remains open if not closed by use of its special property.
rules.18CZ: Moravis-Silesia Variant only: the 3E train is discarded once used, and the MW is closed when purchased by another company.
rules.18GB: The owning player may choose to close the company at any time after the end of the first stock round. In addition, a private company closes if any company builds track in its home hex, which is only possible after the first 4+2 train has been purchased or removed.
rules.18IN: First 6 train. At this point privates 1 to 4 are nationalised, which means they are still closed, but half the face value is paid as compensation to the owners from the bank.
rules.18Ireland: First 8H train.
rules.18Mex: First 5 train, except for the SR, which closes when the fifth 3 train is bought.
rules.18Neb: When the first 5/7 train is bought.
rules.18NK: First 5 train, but the BTS token lasts to the first 6 train.
rules.18NY: First 12H train.
rules.18NYC: First 3E train.
rules.18OE: When its special ability is used, or the owning player closes it during a stock round.
rules.18PA: When converted to the NYC (privates 1-3) or acquired by a company (privates 4-9).
rules.18Ruhr: The BME closes when the first 4 train is sold. The other private companies close if still open when the first 5 train is sold.
rules.18SA: First 6 train, but if the SFP is owned by a company it stays open until the end of the game.
rules.Poseidon: When their special powers are used, except for P4 (Poseidon).
rules.Rolling Stock: When the owner chooses to close them.

rules: 10.6 - Can you buy and sell private companies in other ways?

rules.1825: You can sell them to the bank in a stock round for 30 less than face value. Once they are in the bank pool, they can be bought in a stock round for face value.
rules.1829: If using the optional PC rule, you can sell them to the bank in a stock round for 30 less than face value. Once they are in the bank pool, they can be bought in a stock round for face value.
rules.1858: You can exchange a private for a share in stock rounds and the final exchange round.
rules.1860: You can sell them to the bank in a stock round for 30 less than face value. Once they are in the bank pool, they can be bought in a stock round for face value.
rules.1829 Mainline: You can sell them to the bank in a stock round for 30 less than face value. Once they are in the bank pool, they can be bought in a stock round for face value.
rules.18Africa: Private companies may be sold by players into the bank pool at face value.
rules.Rolling Stock: Throughout the game, new private companies appear and are sold in auctions.

rules: 11.1 - Can the Director's certificate ever be in the bank pool?

rules.1824: No. Note that there is no bank pool as such, so this refers to the bank in general.
rules.1825: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.1826: Yes, after a bankruptcy; but it must then be immediately transferred to a player using the normal change of presidency rules, or the company is permanently closed.
rules.1829: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.1837: Yes, after a bankruptcy.
rules.1841: No, but one can end up there after a bankruptcy, a merger, or the Ferdinandean secession, and is then "freezed".
rules.1853: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.1860: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.1873: No, but it can get there in receivership.
rules.1824 v2: No. Note that there is no bank pool as such, so this refers to the bank in general.
rules.1853 v2: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.1862EA: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.1862EA v2: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.18GB: Yes, and is then operated by official receiver if no other player becomes the Director.
rules.18EU: Yes, after a bankruptcy; but it must then be immediately transferred to a player using the normal change of presidency rules, or the company is permanently closed.
rules: Yes, after a bankruptcy.
rules.1869 USA West: Yes, if the player selling shares is the only player that owns shares in the company. It may also end up in the pool if two or more players hold the same number of shares and more than the current president, or it is not possible to exchange shares with another player following a share sale.
rules.Crisis: No, but it can get there in receivership.
rules.18Ardennes: No, but it can end up there after a bankruptcy.
rules.18Scan: No, but it can end up there after a bankruptcy.
rules.18US: No, but it can end up there after a bankruptcy.
rules.18West: No, but it can end up there after a bankruptcy.
rules.Rolling Stock: Yes, but it will be immediately exchanged for an ordinary share certificate with the new President.

rules:
11.2 - Can you exchange the Director's certificate for regular shares from
another player when you sell shares to the bank pool?

rules.1824: Yes. Note that there is no bank pool as such, so this refers to the bank in general.
rules.1832: Yes. If the new president of a System has any vice-president's certificates, they must be included in the exchange.
rules.1841: For a historic company, only after a 4-train has been bought (presidencies are protected by ownership of concessions).
rules.1881: Yes, but the other player must hold at least 30% of the company.
rules.1898: For a historic company, only after a 4-train has been bought (presidencies are protected by ownership of concessions).
rules.1824 v2: Yes. Note that there is no bank pool as such, so this refers to the bank in general.
rules.1869 USA West: Yes, but only if there is a single player holding the most shares who is also capable of exchanging shares with the current president.
rules.18Lilliput: No, because the Director's certificates are 50% of a total of 80% of shares, so no other player can never have enough to exchange with.
rules.Poseidon: Yes, although this happens at the end of the merchant round, and the player who holds more merchants than the current King may decline the option to take control of the nation.

rules:
11.3 - After a sale of shares forces a change in Director, who gets it in
case of a tie?

rules.1829: Whoever has held the most stock for longest.
rules.1841: Next qualifying human shareholder on seller's left, then companies in order of share value, highest first.
rules.1842: It is offered to the tying players in turn, starting on the seller's left. If the others all refuse, the last one round must accept.
rules.1844: Next qualifying player in SR order.
rules.1873: Next qualifying player in SR order.
rules.1893: Not stated. For convenience of play, treat as stated under 'Rest'.
rules.1898: If a player sells shares: as 1841. If a corporation sells shares: players in seating order, starting with the priority deal, then companies in order of share value, highest first.
rules.1829 Mainline: Not stated. For convenience of play, treat as stated under 'Rest'.
rules: Not stated. For convenience of play, treat as stated under 'Rest'.
rules.Steam Over Holland: Not stated. For convenience of play, treat as stated under 'Rest'.
rules.1830 Cardgame: Not applicable. Shares may not be sold at any time.
rules.Rolling Stock: Next qualifying player in SR order.
rules.one: share in that company for longest.
rules.1869 USA West: Nobody, the certificate goes into the bank pool until one of the tied players (or another player) holds the most shares in the company.
rules.18Lilliput: Not applicable, because Directorships can never change hands.
rules.Crisis: The last qualifying player (not in receivership) in round order.
rules.Poseidon: Next qualifying player on seller's left, although they may decline the option to take control of the nation.
rules.Rest: Next qualifying player on seller's left.

rules: 13.1 - Game ends immediately with a bankruptcy?

rules.1761: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1800: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1812: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1817: No. A player who suffers a cash crisis and is unable to raise the required funds becomes bankrupt and is removed from the game.
rules.1822: No. The player goes into debt instead.
rules.1824: No. The player goes into debt instead.
rules.1825: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1826: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1829: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1831: Yes.
rules.1832: Yes.
rules.1835: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1837: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1841: No. Bankrupt is loaned 500 lire to start again. All assets are taken away from him and may be frozen.
rules.1842: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1844: No. Bankruptcy is not possible. A player needing to raise cash may borrow it from the bank.
rules.1846: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1847: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1848: No. Companies take loans or go into receivership rather than gain financial aid from their director.
rules.1850: Yes.
rules.1853: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1856: Yes.
rules.1858: No. A company does not have to own a train, so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.
rules.1859: Yes.
rules.1860: No. A company that ends its turn with a route but without a train is insolvent, and remains so until it can buy a train.
rules.1861: No. If a player cannot provide sufficient funds to buy a train, loans are taken out to achieve this. If this is still not enough, the company is immediately nationalised.
rules.1862: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1867: No. If a player cannot provide sufficient funds to buy a train, loans are taken out to achieve this. If this is still not enough, the company is immediately nationalised.
rules.1870: Yes.
rules.1873: No. The company goes bankrupt rather than the player.
rules.1880: No. If a player is unable or unwilling to raise the funds to buy a train for a company, the player incurs a 50% interest charge on the remaining debt.
rules.1881: No. A bankrupt player leaves the game.
rules.1883: Not usually. The bankrupt player's wealth is reduced to zero and they take no further part in the game. If all players but one have gone bankrupt, the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.1891: Yes.
rules.1898: Yes.

No. Companies go into receivership rather than gain financial aid from their president.
rules.18??: Yes.
rules.18C2C: Yes.
rules.18NK: Yes.
rules.18NW: Yes.
rules.18NYC: Yes.
rules.1830 v2: No. The company gains a bank loan to cover the balance required to buy a train and goes into receivership, and is managed by the president, who must use the company revenue to pay off the loan. When the loan is fully repaid the company comes out of receivership.
rules.1830BC: Not immediately, but at the end of the next rainy season.
rules.18CZ: No.
rules.18GM: No.
rules.18OE: No.
rules.18SA: No.
rules.1849v4: No. The company goes bankrupt rather than the player. If the player has zero wealth at this point, they can take a loan of L500 or leave the game. If they take the loan, L750 is subtracted from their total at the end of the game.
rules.18GB: No. A company that ends its turn with a route but without a train is insolvent, and remains so until it can buy a train.
rules.1862EA: No. Players cannot go bankrupt because they are enever required to help a company finance a train. If a company goes bankrupt players receive compensation for their shares as long as the company has a positive share price.
rules.1862EA v2: No. Players cannot go bankrupt because they are enever required to help a company finance a train. If a company goes bankrupt players receive compensation for their shares as long as the company has a positive share price.
rules.1865 Sardinia: No. The player is given sufficient State Aid loans to purchase a train and continues playing.
rules.1869 The Golden Spike: No. If a player would go bankrupt, they reorganise the company they were trying to buy a train for.
rules.Rolling Stock: No. The company goes bankrupt rather than the player.
rules.Steam Over Holland: No. The company goes bankrupt rather than the player.
rules.18BL: No. A bankrupt player leaves the game.
rules.18CLE: No. A bankrupt player leaves the game.
rules.18Ruhr: No. A bankrupt player leaves the game.
rules.18SS: No. A bankrupt player leaves the game.
rules.18IN: It depends which rule you prefer. According to rule 4.7.2, if a player becomes bankrupt the game ends immediately. According to rule 5, if all players but one have gone bankrupt the game ends with the remaining player as the winner.
rules.18Ireland: Only if all players bar one have become bankrupt.
rules.Crisis: Immediately after execution of all supports.
rules.Poseidon: Not immediately, but at the end of the next empire round.
rules.Railroad Barons: No. A company does not have to own a train (referring to railroad corporations), so a player is never at risk of bankruptcy.

rules:
13.2 - What happens if the bank runs out of money during an operating
round?

rules.1761: Nothing. The bank holds 12,000, but is effectively unlimited.
rules.1800: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1812: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1817: Nothing. The bank holds 12,000, but is effectively unlimited.
rules.1825: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1829: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1831: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1835: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1837: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1841: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1842: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1847: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1851: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1853: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1858: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1860: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1861: If this happens before the first 8 train has been bought, the game ends when the current operating round is completed. If the first 8 train has been bought, the game ends after a set of three operating rounds. If the 8 train is bought in the first operating round of a set, complete the round and play two more operating rounds. Otherwise, complete the round, play a stock round and then play three more operating rounds.
rules.1867: If this happens before the first 8 train has been bought, the game ends when the current operating round is completed. If the first 8 train has been bought, the game ends after a set of three operating rounds. If the 8 train is bought in the first operating round of a set, complete the round and play two more operating rounds. Otherwise, complete the round, play a stock round and then play three more operating rounds.
rules.1873: The bank has unlimited money.
rules.1880: Nothing. The bank holds 37,860, but is effectively unlimited.
rules.1898: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18USA: Nothing. The bank holds 12,000, but is effectively unlimited.
rules.1829 Mainline: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1837SX: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1838 Rheinland: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1853 v2: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1876-35: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18Africa: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18AL: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18CLE: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18Dixie: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18GA: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18GA v2: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18Mex: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18TN: Game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.1822CA: Game ends when the current set of operating rounds plus one additional operating round is completed.
rules.18GB: The bank has unlimited money.
rules.18CZ: Nothing. The bank holds 13,840, but is effectively unlimited.
rules.18EZ Level 1: Bank will issue IOUs if needed - does not technically run out of money.
rules.18Lilliput: The game ends after the 8th round (9th round in 3 player games). The bank is presumably not expected to run out.
rules.18MS: The game ends after 10 operating rounds.
rules.18OE: If prior to the purchase of an 8 train, game ends when the current operating round is completed.
rules.18Ruhr: Game ends when the current set of operating rounds is completed. The rules state that this happens when the bank runs out of money from phase 5 onwards. Presumably it is not expected that the bank will run out earlier than this.
rules.Poseidon: The game ends after the 11th empire round. The bank is presumably not expected to run out.
rules.Railroad Barons: Not stated. The bank holds 16,512 and is probably never expected to run out.
rules.Steam Over Holland: The game ends after 15 rounds (5 stock rounds and 10 operating rounds). The bank is presumably not expected to run out.
rules.Rest: Game ends when the current set of operating rounds is completed.

rules.1817: Nothing.

rules.1824: Nothing.
rules.1826: Nothing.
rules.1831: Stock splits, price drops but each share is worth double market value until sold.
rules.1832: Nothing.
rules.1837: Nothing.

rules.18OE: If prior to the purchase of an 8 train, complete one more operating round.
rules.18Ruhr: The players combine to put 600 Mark into the bank, repeating if necessary to give the bank a positive balance. The rules say nothing about how to handle situations where one or more playes has insufficient funds to contribute to this activity.
rules.Poseidon: The game ends after the 11th empire round. The bank is presumably not expected to run out.
rules.Railroad Barons: Not stated. The bank holds 16,512 and is probably never expected to run out.
rules.Steam Over Holland: The game ends after 15 rounds (5 stock rounds and 10 operating rounds). The bank is presumably not expected to run out.

rules: 15.1 - Total cash in game

1812:
4,000 for 2 players
    6,000 for 3 players
    8,000 for 4 players
1825:
Originally intended to be 4,000 for Unit 1, but initial sets were erroneously issued
    with 2,600; later increased to 5,000; Lawson sets include 6,000
    5,000 for Unit 2
    4,000 for Unit 3
1831:
10,000 plus 2,000 times number of players for standard bank - add 10,000 for extended
    game
1846:
6,500 for three players
    7,500 for four players
    9,000 for five players
1848: 10,000 plus 2,000 for the Bank of England
1849: 7,760 used for game (8,040 supplied in set)
1830 Cardgame: Not stated, assumed to be unlimited
1853 v2:
15,000 - the game is supplied with 17,760 and the amount you use can be increased or
    decreased to change the length of the game
1865 Sardinia:
8,000 for the normal game
    6,000 for the short game
18C2C: 48,000 for the standard game, 36,000 for the short game
Steam Over Holland: 5,640 (not stated in the rules, counted from my set)
